words.name: vals
words.markdown:
activates an empty Stack for the duration of Block.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] vals leaves: [ 1 2 3 ]
[ (1 2 + 2 *) 'hello' ] vals leaves: [ 6 'hello' ]
```
words.primer: activates an empty Stack for the duration of Block.

words.name: val
words.markdown:
activates an empty stack for the duration of Block, and leaves Top form in the stack. Dies if none.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] val leaves: 3
[ 'foo' 'bar' ~ ] val leaves: 'foobar'
```
words.primer: activates an empty stack for the duration of Block, and leaves Top form in the stack.

words.name: 2val
words.markdown:
activates individual empty stacks for each of the two Blocks, and leaves their corresponding Top forms.

```
[ 1 2 + ] [ 3 4 + ] 2val leaves: [ 3 7 ]
```
words.primer: activates individual empty stacks for each of the two Blocks, and leaves their corresponding Top forms.

words.name: thruLitBlock
words.markdown:
leaves Literal block after cursor in Block. If form after cursor isn't a block, encloses it and opens it with an empty stack, Block being the enclosing block's parent, and finally asserts the resulting form is a block.

```
[ 'Hello World' ] $: x
[ | x [ 4 ] ] $: foo

foo thruLitBlock leaves: [[ 'Hello World' ]]
foo toQuote leaves: '[ x | [ 4 ] ]'

foo thruLitBlock leaves: [[ 4 ]]
foo toQuote leaves: '[ x [ 4 ] ]'
```
words.primer: leaves Literal block after cursor in Block.

words.name: thruWord
words.markdown: same as `thru asWord`.
words.primer: same as `thru asWord`.

words.name: thruWord:
words.markdown:
same as `thruWord`, but also checks if the `thru`-ed word is the same as Word.

```
[ ahead thruVal $: begin
  ahead thruWord: to:
  ahead thruVal $: end

  begin to: end
] @: from:

from: 1 to: 100 leaves: [ 1 2 3 "…" 98 99 100 ]
```
words.primer: same as `thruWord`, but also checks if the `thru`-ed word is the same as Word.

words.name: thruVal
words.markdown: same as `thruBlock val`.
words.primer: same as `thruBlock val`.

words.name: thruVals
words.markdown: same as `thruBlock vals`.
words.primer: same as `thruBlock vals`.

words.name: obj
words.markdown:
like `do`, but leaves the resulting Instance of Block. Equivalent to `[ <Block> this ] do`.

```
[ 100 $: x 200 $: y ] obj "[ 100 $: x 200 $: y · ${x :: 100} {y :: 200} ]"

bi: [ .x ] [ .y ] leaves: [ 100 200 ]
```
words.primer: like `do`, but leaves the resulting Instance of Block.

words.name: sel:
words.markdown:
infix version of `sel`.

```
(0 randTo: 100) odd? sel: 'Yay!' 'Nay!' echo
```
words.primer: infix version of `sel`.

words.name: br:
words.markdown:
infix version of `br`.

```
(0 randTo: 100) odd? br:
  [ 'Yay!' echo ]
  [ 'Nay!' echo ]

"Say no to repetition!"
(0 randTo: 100) odd? (br: 'Yay!' 'Nay!') echo
```
words.primer: infix version of `br`.

words.markdown:
opens True branch form if Determiner is truthy.

```
(0 randTo: 100) even? => [ 'Okay it is even!' echo ]
```
words.primer: opens True branch form if Determiner is truthy.

words.name: or:
words.markdown:
opens False branch form if Determiner is falsey. Infix inverse of `=>`.

```
(0 randTo: 100) even? or: [ 'Nah it is odd' echo ]
```
words.primer: opens False branch form if Determiner is falsey.

words.markdown:
opens True branch form if Determiner is truthy.

If Determiner is a block, creates a copy of the stack and opens Determiner with that stack. If Determiner leaves a truthy form, opens True branch form with the old stack. Otherwise, does nothing.

```
100 even? ~> 1 leaves: [ 1 ]
101 even? ~> 1 leaves: [ ]

100 ([ even? ] ~> [ 2 * ]) leaves: [ 200 ]
101 ([ even? ] ~> [ 2 * ]) leaves: [ 101 ]

2 4 ([ * even? ] ~> +) leaves: 6
5 5 ([ * even? ] ~> +) leaves: [ 5 5 ]
```
words.primer: opens True branch form if Determiner is truthy.

words.name: and
words.markdown:
leaves whether both A and B are truthy.

Supports short-circuiting. Remember that in Novika, only `false` itself is falsey. Everything else is truthy.

```
(false false and) leaves: false
(true false and) leaves: false
(false true and) leaves: false
(true true and) leaves: true

(100 200 and) leaves: true
(100 false and) leaves: false

[ 100 even? ] [ 200 odd? ] and leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether both A and B are truthy.

words.name: or
words.markdown:
leaves whether A or B or both are truthy.

Supports short-circuiting. Remember that in Novika, only `false` itself is falsey. Everything else is truthy.

```
(false false or) leaves: false
(true false or) leaves: true
(false true or) leaves: true
(true true or) leaves: true

(100 200 or) leaves: true
(100 false or) leaves: true

[ 100 even? ] [ 200 odd? ] or leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether A or B or both are truthy.

words.name: neither?
words.markdown:
same as `or not`, leaves whether neither A nor B is truthy.

Supports short-circuiting. Remember that in Novika, only `false` itself is falsey. Everything else is truthy.

```
[ 100 odd? ] [ 201 even? ] neither? leaves: true
```
words.primer: same as `or not`, leaves whether neither A nor B is truthy.

words.name: continues
words.markdown: makes shallow copy of continuations stack the stack for the duration of Block. Replaces substrate of the continuation stack with the modified shallow copy after Block is opened.
words.primer: makes shallow copy of continuations stack the stack for the duration of Block.

words.name: repeat
words.markdown:
executes caller again. Looping primitive. Too low- level for users, prefer not to use (use `loop` instead). Beware that it does not re-instantiate the block.

```
[
  'Looping indefinitely, yay!' echo

  repeat
] do
```
words.primer: executes caller again.

words.name: dropContinuationsUntil
words.markdown: drops all continuations before (and including) those for which Block leaves truthy value when opened with the continuation on top of an empty stack, coming from the right-hand side.
words.primer: drops all continuations before (and including) those for which Block leaves truthy value when opened with the continuation on top of an empty stack, coming from the right-hand side.

words.markdown: closes blocks all the way up to, and including, its *opener's parent*.
words.primer: closes blocks all the way up to, and including, its *opener's parent*.

words.name: createLoop
words.markdown:
takes an Iteration body block and leaves three handles: Start handle to start the loop, Next handle to continue the loop, and Break handle to break the loop.

```
[ '> ' readLine or: nextCycle
  [ 'quit' quitLoop
    'next' nextCycle
  ] choose
  'You have entered: ' swap ~ echo
] createLoop
  @: nextCycle
  @: quitLoop
  @: startLoop

'Hello! Type `quit` to quit!' echo
  startLoop
'Bye!' echo
```
words.primer: takes an Iteration body block and leaves three handles: Start handle to start the loop, Next handle to continue the loop, and Break handle to break the loop.

words.name: createDetachedLoop
words.markdown:
defines `break` and `next` for a Body block that is being evaluated indirectly by a Control block, and only if Condition leaves a truthy value on top of the stack it hydrated. `next` resumes the Control block. Leaves Start handle to start the loop.

```
"Body block is the 'client' block of sorts:"
[ dup even? (br: ' is even!' ' is odd!') ~ echo
] $: bodyBlock


0 $: n

"Control block chooses whether, and how to run
the body block."
[ n enclose bodyBlock hydrate
  n 1 + =: n
] $: controlBlock

"Condition block chooses whether to stop looping."
[ n 5 <
] $: conditionBlock

bodyBlock conditionBlock controlBlock createDetachedLoop
  @: startLoop

startLoop

"STDOUT: 0 is even!⏎"
"STDOUT: 1 is odd!⏎"
"STDOUT: 2 is even!⏎"
"STDOUT: 3 is odd!⏎"
"STDOUT: 4 is even!⏎"

n leaves: 5
```
words.primer: defines `break` and `next` for a Body block that is being evaluated indirectly by a Control block, and only if Condition leaves a truthy value on top of the stack it hydrated.

words.name: loop
words.markdown:
basic infinite loop over an Iteration body block. `break` and `next` are available in the block. A new stack created for each iteration.

```
'Hello! Type `quit` to quit!' echo

[ '> ' readLine or: next
  [ 'quit' break
    'next' next
  ] choose
  'You have entered: ' swap ~ echo
] loop

'Bye!' echo
```
words.primer: basic infinite loop over an Iteration body block.

words.name: loop:
words.markdown: prefix version of `loop`.
words.primer: prefix version of `loop`.

words.name: while
words.markdown:
hydrates an empty stack with Condition; if ToS is truthy afterwards, Block is opened over an empty stack. Repeats until ToS is false. Similar to `loop`, words `break` and `next` are available in Block.

```
1 to: 10 sample: 10 p $: numbers

0 $: index

while: [ numbers index fromLeft even? ]
[
  index 1 + =: index
  index (numbers count) = => [
    'No odd numbers :(' echo
    okbye
  ]
]

'First odd number is: ' (numbers index fromLeft) ~ echo
```
words.primer: hydrates an empty stack with Condition; if ToS is truthy afterwards, Block is opened over an empty stack.

words.name: while:
words.markdown: prefix version of `while`.
words.primer: prefix version of `while`.

words.name: until
words.markdown:
inverse of `while` (opens Block while Condition is **false**), for more info see `while`.

```
1 to: 10 sample: 10 p $: numbers

0 $: index

until: [ numbers index fromLeft odd? ]
[
  index 1 + =: index
  index (numbers count) = => [
    'No odd numbers :(' echo
    okbye
  ]
]

'First odd number is: ' (numbers index fromLeft) ~ echo
```
words.primer: inverse of `while` (opens Block while Condition is **false**), for more info see `while`.

words.name: until:
words.markdown: prefix version of `until`.
words.primer: prefix version of `until`.

words.name: times
words.markdown:
opens Block Count times. For each iteration of Block, a new stack block is activated with current Count on top. `break` and `next` available.

```
16 times: [
  even? ~> next
  9 >= ~> break
  echo
]

"STDOUT: 1⏎"
"STDOUT: 3⏎"
"STDOUT: 5⏎"
"STDOUT: 7⏎"
```
words.primer: opens Block Count times.

words.name: times:
words.markdown: infix version of `times`.
words.primer: infix version of `times`.

words.name: compiledTimes
words.markdown:
**unsafe** `times` alternative for when you *really* need to iterate a lot.

This word basically strips off all steps in the `createDetachedLoop` (aka structured control flow) abstraction ladder.

Internally, it's a bit like your Block being followed by a GOTO back to the beginning, plus a counter *on the stack*.

Note that the loop is *compiled* from a template when you use this word. **This means that opening this word multiple times in a row is inefficient**, as such compilation is expensive. However, if you need to *iterate* quickly, you can try using this word.

The stack your Block is given is *not* owned by you. You must not leave junk, and you must not drop the index. The effect of your block **must** be `( I -- I )`.

`next` and `break` are **not** supported.

```
10_000 compiledTimes: [ $: index
  index 2 * echo
  index
]
```
words.primer: **unsafe** `times` alternative for when you *really* need to iterate a lot.

words.name: compiledTimes:
words.markdown:
infix version of `compiledTimes`.

```
0 $: acc
100_000 compiledTimes: [ "( I -- I )"
  dup acc + =: acc
]
acc echo "STDOUT: 5000050000⏎"
```
words.primer: infix version of `compiledTimes`.

words.name: withColorEcho
words.markdown:
echoes Form like `withColorAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.

```
0 100 0 rgb withEchoFg
100 0 0 rgb withEchoBg
  'Hi!' withColorEcho
dropEchoBg
  'Bye!' withColorEcho
dropEchoFg
```
words.primer: echoes Form like `withColorAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.

words.name: withEmphasisEcho
words.markdown: echoes Form like `withEmphasisAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.
words.primer: echoes Form like `withEmphasisAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.

words.name: withReverseEcho
words.markdown: echoes Form like `withReverseAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.
words.primer: echoes Form like `withReverseAppendEcho`, then echoes a newline character.

words.name: 2asc
words.markdown:
sorts two decimals, A and B, in ascending (Low to High) order. If A = B, the order is unchanged (this is relevant for blocks implementing `__decimal__`).

```
1 2 2asc leaves: [ 1 2 ]
2 1 2asc leaves: [ 1 2 ]
```
words.primer: sorts two decimals, A and B, in ascending (Low to High) order.

words.name: 2desc
words.markdown:
sorts two decimals, A and B, in descending (High to Low) order. If A = B, the order is unchanged (this is relevant for blocks implementing `__decimal__`).

```
1 2 2desc leaves: [ 2 1 ]
2 1 2desc leaves: [ 2 1 ]
```
words.primer: sorts two decimals, A and B, in descending (High to Low) order.

words.name: 2min
words.markdown:
leaves Low (minimum) decimal of the two decimals A and B. If you're curious, the words "high" and "low" are used because "minimum" and "maximum" start with the same letter, which would end up being pretty confusing doc comment-wise.

```
3 10 2min leaves: 3
```
words.primer: leaves Low (minimum) decimal of the two decimals A and B.

words.name: 2max
words.markdown:
leaves High (maximum) decimal of the two decimals A and B. If you're curious, the words "high" and "low" are used because "minimum" and "maximum" start with the same letter, which would end up being pretty confusing doc comment-wise.

```
3 10 2max leaves: 10
```
words.primer: leaves High (maximum) decimal of the two decimals A and B.

words.name: randFromTo
words.markdown: generates random Decimal between Low and High, *including* both Low and High.
words.primer: generates random Decimal between Low and High, *including* both Low and High.

words.name: randTo:
words.markdown:
infix version of `randFromTo`.

```
1 randTo: 100 leaves: [ "a random decimal within [1; 100]" ]

[ ask: 'L = ' parseDecimal ]
  randTo: [ ask: 'H = ' parseDecimal ]
  leaves: [ "a random decimal based on user input"]
  echo
```
words.primer: infix version of `randFromTo`.

words.name: clamp:
words.markdown:
clamps Number between Low and High: if Number is less than Low, leaves low; if Number is greater than High, leaves High.

```
1 clamp: 5 10 leaves: 5
5 clamp: 5 10 leaves: 5
7 clamp: 5 10 leaves: 7
10 clamp: 5 10 leaves: 10
100 clamp: 5 10 leaves: 10
```
words.primer: clamps Number between Low and High: if Number is less than Low, leaves low; if Number is greater than High, leaves High.

words.name: flipSign
words.markdown:
flips the sign of N.

```
-1 flipSign leaves: 1
0 flipSign leaves: 0
1 flipSign leaves: -1
```
words.primer: flips the sign of N. ``` -1 flipSign leaves: 1 0 flipSign leaves: 0 1 flipSign leaves: -1 ```

words.name: abs
words.markdown:
leaves the Absolute value of N.

```
0 abs leaves: 0
100 abs leaves: 100
-100 abs leaves: 100
```
words.primer: leaves the Absolute value of N. ``` 0 abs leaves: 0 100 abs leaves: 100 -100 abs leaves: 100 ```

words.markdown:
leaves Reciprocal of Decimal (`1/D`). Leaves 0 if Decimal is 0. Note: as in `12 % 12 *`, this may not always leave `1` because of math imprecisions.

```
0 % leaves: 0
20 % leaves: 0.05
100 % 100 * leaves: 1
```
words.primer: leaves Reciprocal of Decimal (`1/D`).

words.name: rangesMap
words.effect: ( D R1b R1e R2b R2e -- D' ):
words.markdown:
leaves Decimal in range [R1b; R1e] mapped to the range [R2b; R2e].

Note: Decimal is clamped into the range [R1b; R1e]. Note: implementation taken from https://www.arduino.cc/reference/en/language/functions/math/map/

```
100  0 100  1.5 255  rangesMap leaves: 255
  0  0 100  1.5 255  rangesMap leaves: 1.5

"Reverse range:"

10  0 100  100 0  rangesMap leaves: 90
```
words.primer: leaves Decimal in range [R1b; R1e] mapped to the range [R2b; R2e].

words.name: mapFromRange:
words.effect: ( D mapFromRange: R1b R1e toRange: R2b R2e -- D' ):
words.markdown:
infix version of `rangesMap`.

```
100 mapFromRange: 0 100 toRange: 1.5 255 leaves: [ 255 ]
  0 mapFromRange: 0 100 toRange: 1.5 255 leaves: [ 1.5 ]
```
words.primer: infix version of `rangesMap`.

words.name: mapToRange
words.markdown:
leaves Decimal in range [Range begin; Range end] corresponding to the given Percentage (in [0; 1]).

See `rangesMap` for more details.

```
"...etc.."
-100  0 100  mapToRange leaves: 0
   0  0 100  mapToRange leaves: 0
 0.1  0 100  mapToRange leaves: 10
   1  0 100  mapToRange leaves: 100
   2  0 100  mapToRange leaves: 100
"...etc.."
```
words.primer: leaves Decimal in range [Range begin; Range end] corresponding to the given Percentage (in [0; 1]).

words.name: mapToRange:
words.markdown: infix version of `mapToRange`.
words.primer: infix version of `mapToRange`.

words.name: %of:
words.markdown:
leaves Decimal, which is Human percentage (0-100) mapped to [Range begin; Range end] range. Human percentage is clamped to 0-100.

```
"What is 30% of John's salary, $10 000? "
(30 %of: 0 10_000) leaves: 3000
(60 %of: 64 255) leaves: 178.6
```
words.primer: leaves Decimal, which is Human percentage (0-100) mapped to [Range begin; Range end] range.

words.name: to%:
words.markdown:
leaves Human percentage for Decimal in the given range [Range begin; Range end]. Inverse of `%of:`.

```
(100 to%: 0 256) leaves: 39.0625

"You can verify the result like so:"
(39.0625 %of: 0 256) leaves: 100
```
words.primer: leaves Human percentage for Decimal in the given range [Range begin; Range end].

words.name: deg->rad
words.markdown: leaves Angle in radians for the given Angle in degrees.
words.primer: leaves Angle in radians for the given Angle in degrees.

words.name: rad->deg
words.markdown: leaves Angle in degrees for the given Angle in radians.
words.primer: leaves Angle in degrees for the given Angle in radians.

words.name: approx=
words.markdown: leaves Boolean for whether A and B are approximately equal (their difference is less than or equal to `EPSILON`).
words.primer: leaves Boolean for whether A and B are approximately equal (their difference is less than or equal to `EPSILON`).

words.markdown: leaves whether A <= B.
words.primer: leaves whether A <= B.

words.markdown: leaves whether A > B.
words.primer: leaves whether A > B.

words.markdown: leaves whether A >= B.
words.primer: leaves whether A >= B.

words.name: zero?
words.markdown: leaves whether A = 0
words.primer: leaves whether A = 0

words.name: positive?
words.markdown: leaves whether A >= 0
words.primer: leaves whether A >= 0

words.name: negative?
words.markdown: leaves whether A < 9
words.primer: leaves whether A < 9

words.markdown: leaves whether A is divisible by B.
words.primer: leaves whether A is divisible by B.

words.name: even?
words.markdown: leaves whether A is even (divisible by two).
words.primer: leaves whether A is even (divisible by two).

words.name: odd?
words.markdown: leaves whether A is odd.
words.primer: leaves whether A is odd.

words.name: empty?
words.markdown: leaves whether Block is empty.
words.primer: leaves whether Block is empty.

words.name: false?
words.markdown: Leaves whether Form is `false`.
words.primer: Leaves whether Form is `false`.

words.name: true?
words.markdown: converts Form into boolean.
words.primer: converts Form into boolean.

words.name: not
words.markdown: leaves inverse boolean for Form.
words.primer: leaves inverse boolean for Form.

words.name: toCapitalized
words.markdown: capitalizes Quote: transforms the first letter of Quote to uppercase.
words.primer: capitalizes Quote: transforms the first letter of Quote to uppercase.

words.markdown:
obtains Quote by stitching (and enquoting, if necessary) two forms, A and B.

```
100 200 ~ leaves: '100200'
'hello' 'world' ~ leaves: 'helloworld'
```
words.primer: obtains Quote by stitching (and enquoting, if necessary) two forms, A and B.

words.markdown:
like `here join`, but faster and not recursive in case Form is a block. Else, same as `toQuote`. Leaves the resulting Quote.

```
123 ~* leaves: '123'
[ 1 2 3 ] ~* leaves: '123'

'John' $: name
[ 'My name is ' name '!' ] ~* leaves: 'My name is John!'
```

Beware that the referenced entries are only resolved. They are not opened. Consider using `vals join` if you want to stitch results instead.

```
[ 1 2 + ] @: foo

[ 'foo = ' foo ] ~* leaves: 'foo = [ 1 2 + ]'

"You can use this if you want to evaluate first:"
[ 'foo = ' foo ] vals join leaves: 'foo = 3'
```
words.primer: like `here join`, but faster and not recursive in case Form is a block.

words.name: parseDecimal
words.markdown:
converts Quote to Decimal. Dies if Quote does not contain a decimal, or if couldn't parse it out.

Quote is parsed by Novika. This word only ensures the result of that is a decimal. Aside from error messages that leak this fact, you generally shouldn't care about this.

```
'1234' parseDecimal leaves: 1234
'-1234.5678' parseDecimal leaves: -1234.5678
```
words.primer: converts Quote to Decimal.

words.name: 2drop
words.markdown:
drops a pair of forms.

```
1 2 2drop leaves: [ ]
```
words.primer: drops a pair of forms.

words.name: nip
words.markdown:
drops a form under the top.

```
1 2 nip leaves: [ 2 ]
```
words.primer: drops a form under the top.

words.name: nup
words.markdown:
duplicates a form under the top.

```
1 2 nup leaves: [ 1 1 2 ]
```
words.primer: duplicates a form under the top.

words.name: over
words.markdown:
duplicates a form over the top.

```
1 2 over leaves: [ 1 2 1 ]
```
words.primer: duplicates a form over the top.

words.name: tuck
words.markdown:
puts a duplicate of the top form before the second-from-top form.

```
1 2 tuck leaves: [ 2 1 2 ]
```
words.primer: puts a duplicate of the top form before the second-from-top form.

words.name: 2dup
words.effect: ( A B -- A B A B ):
words.markdown:
duplicates a pair of forms.

```
1 2 2dup leaves: [ 1 2 1 2 ]
```
words.primer: duplicates a pair of forms.

words.name: rot
words.effect: ( A B C -- B C A ):
words.markdown:
moves thirdmost form to the top.

```
1 2 3 rot leaves: [ 2 3 1 ]
      rot leaves: [ 3 1 2 ]
      rot leaves: [ 1 2 3 ]
```
words.primer: moves thirdmost form to the top.

words.name: -rot
words.effect: ( A B C -- C A B ):
words.markdown:
moves top form so it's thirdmost.

```
1 2 3 -rot leaves: [ 3 1 2 ]
      -rot leaves: [ 2 3 1 ]
      -rot leaves: [ 1 2 3 ]
```
words.primer: moves top form so it's thirdmost.

words.name: asStack
words.markdown: replaces current stack with Block in-place. Cursor position is saved (clamped to Block end if Block is smaller)
words.primer: replaces current stack with Block in-place.

words.name: dip
words.markdown:
opens Form behind Top form.

```
1 2 4 [ + ] dip leaves: [ 3 4 ]
1 2 4 100 dip leaves: [ 1 2 100 4 ]
```
words.primer: opens Form behind Top form.

words.name: dip:
words.markdown: infix version of `dip`.
words.primer: infix version of `dip`.

words.name: keep
words.markdown:
opens Form with Top form on top of the stack. Restores Top form afterwards.

```
1 2 4 [ + ] keep leaves: [ 1 6 4 ]
1 2 4 'hello' keep leaves: [ 1 2 4 'hello' 4 ]
```
words.primer: opens Form with Top form on top of the stack.

words.name: keep:
words.markdown: infix version of `keep`.
words.primer: infix version of `keep`.

words.name: bi
words.markdown:
opens two blocks, A and B, with Form placed on top of the stack for each one, and leaves their results in order.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] [ sum ] [ count ] bi / leaves: 2
```
words.primer: opens two blocks, A and B, with Form placed on top of the stack for each one, and leaves their results in order.

words.name: bi:
words.effect: ( F bi: A B -- A' B' ):
words.markdown:
infix version of `bi`.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] bi: sum count / leaves: 2
```
words.primer: infix version of `bi`.

words.name: bi*
words.effect: ( Af Bf A B -- A' B' ):
words.markdown:
opens block A with A form, block B with B form, and leaves the results.

Note: the result of opening A is available to B.

```
[ 1 2 ] [ 3 4 ] [ first ] [ last ] bi* leaves: [ 1 4 ]

"Note how we use the result of the first block in the
 second block:"
[ 1 2 ] [ 3 4 ] [ first ] [ last + ] bi* leaves: [ 5 ]
```
words.primer: opens block A with A form, block B with B form, and leaves the results.

words.name: bi*:
words.effect: ( Af Bf bi*: A B -- A' B' ):
words.markdown: infix version of `bi*`.
words.primer: infix version of `bi*`.

words.name: bi@
words.markdown:
leaves the results of applying Block first to X form, and then to Y form.

```
1 2 [ 'X =' swap ~ ] bi@ leaves: [ 'X = 1' 'X = 2' ]
```
words.primer: leaves the results of applying Block first to X form, and then to Y form.

words.name: bi@:
words.effect: ( X Y bi@: B -- Bx By ):
words.markdown: infix version of `bi@`.
words.primer: infix version of `bi@`.

words.markdown:
moves cursor left twice in the active stack, opposite of `|>>`. Same as `<| <|` but looks nicer.

```
[ a b c | ] |: [ <<| 123 |>> 456 ] leaves: [ [ a 123 b c 456 ] ]
```
words.primer: moves cursor left twice in the active stack, opposite of `|>>`.

words.markdown:
moves cursor right twice in the active stack, opposite of `<<|`. Same as `|> |>` but looks nicer.

See `<<|` for an example of how you can use this word.
words.primer: moves cursor right twice in the active stack, opposite of `<<|`.

words.name: echo
words.markdown: enquotes Form, and appends the resulting quote, followed by newline, to the standard output stream.
words.primer: enquotes Form, and appends the resulting quote, followed by newline, to the standard output stream.

words.name: say:
words.markdown:
infix version of `echo`.

```
say: 'Hello World'
say: [ 1 2 + ]
```

The above prints:

```text
Hello World
3
```
words.primer: infix version of `echo`.

words.name: help
words.markdown: echoes help for Form. If form is a word, fetches it in caller first.
words.primer: echoes help for Form.

words.name: 2echo
words.markdown: echoes a pair of Forms.
words.primer: echoes a pair of Forms.

words.name: p
words.markdown: echoes a Form but leaves it on the stack.
words.primer: echoes a Form but leaves it on the stack.

words.name: 2p
words.markdown: echoes a pair of Forms but leaves them on the stack.
words.primer: echoes a pair of Forms but leaves them on the stack.

words.name: ask
words.markdown: same as `readLine`, but Answer quote is left even if the user rejected the prompt (in such case it is empty).
words.primer: same as `readLine`, but Answer quote is left even if the user rejected the prompt (in such case it is empty).

words.name: ask:
words.markdown:
infix version of `ask`.

```
ask: 'What is your name? ' $: name
say: [ ['Nice to meet you, ' name '!'] ~* ]
```
words.primer: infix version of `ask`.

words.name: measure
words.markdown: leaves Monotonic time difference in milliseconds for Block (leaves the time Block took to execute, in ms).
words.primer: leaves Monotonic time difference in milliseconds for Block (leaves the time Block took to execute, in ms).

words.name: okbye
words.markdown: ends the program with the exit code 1 (an error).
words.primer: ends the program with the exit code 1 (an error).

words.name: newBlockSet
words.markdown:
a set-like data structure for storing blocks (and only blocks) by their address, or some other property based on the key (mapper) block, see `::set::/keyBy` .

Entry order (and iteration order) is exactly the insertion order.

Exposes the following words: `add[:]`, `remove[:]`, `has?` and `has:`, `each[:]`, `keyBy[:]`.

```
newBlockSet $: set

[ 1 2 ] $: foo
[ 3 4 ] $: bar
[ 1 2 ] $: baz

set.add: foo
set.add: bar

set.has: foo leaves: true
set.has: bar leaves: true
set.has: baz leaves: false

set.remove: bar
set.has: bar leaves: false

set.add: baz
set.has: baz leaves: true

set.each: [ echo ]
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 ]⏎[ 1 2 ]⏎"

"The first printed block is `foo` and the second is `baz`.
 Despite looking the same, they are different blocks stored
 at different addresses!"
```
words.primer: a set-like data structure for storing blocks (and only blocks) by their address, or some other property based on the key (mapper) block, see `::set::/keyBy` .

words.markdown:
same as `$:` but allows to define multiple pusher Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

```
[ ${ x y } this ] @: point

100 200 point -> [ x y ]
  leaves: [ [ 100 200 ] ]
```
words.primer: same as `$:` but allows to define multiple pusher Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

words.markdown:
same as `@:`, but allows to define multiple opener Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

```
[ @{ x y }

  [ bi*: [x +] [y +] ={ x y } ] @: move

  this
] @: point

"Point A has decimals under X and Y"
100 200 point $: A

"Point B is inset some..."
[ A.x 10 + ] [ A.y 5 + ] point $: B

A.x A.y leaves: [ 100 200 ]
B.x B.y leaves: [ 110 205 ]

"Move A some..."
10 10 A.move

A.x A.y leaves: [ 110 210 ]
B.x B.y leaves: [ 120 215 ]
```
words.primer: same as `@:`, but allows to define multiple opener Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

words.markdown:
same as `=:`, but allows to submit multiple Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

```
[ @{ x y }

  [ ={ x y } ] @: update

  this
] @: point

0 0 point $: A

A.x A.y leaves: [ 0 0 ]

100 200 A.update

A.x A.y leaves: [ 100 200 ]
```
words.primer: same as `=:`, but allows to submit multiple Entries simultaneously, and in the 'human-readable' order.

words.name: choose
words.markdown:
high-level conditional. Acts similar to `case` or `switch` in other languages. Takes a Form to match over, and a Case list in the form `[ Condition Case-Body Condition Case-Body ... ]`. Leaves the result of Case body corresponding to the condition that matched Form, otherwise (if no cases matched), Form itself.

```novika
1 to: 100 each: [
  [ [ 15 /? ] 'FizzBuzz'
    [  5 /? ] 'Buzz'
    [  3 /? ] 'Fizz'
  ] choose echo
]
```
words.primer: high-level conditional.

words.markdown:
same as `swap`, but is more readable and compact in certain scenarios.

```
[ 'Judy' 'Mark' 'Fabian' 'Huggee' ] $: pets

orphan $: ages

pets each: [
  ages _ (0 randTo: 15) pushes
]

"Your numbers will probably be different because we're
 generating them randomly:"
ages -> 'Judy' leaves: 1
ages -> 'Mark' leaves: 8
ages -> 'Fabian' leaves: 11
ages -> 'Huggee' leaves: 14
```
words.primer: same as `swap`, but is more readable and compact in certain scenarios.

words.name: runTestsInGroup:
words.markdown:
runs all test cases in the given Group. Reports to the standard output stream. Dies if Group doesn't exist. Leaves whether *all* tests succeeded.

See `describe` for an example.
words.primer: runs all test cases in the given Group.

words.name: describe
words.markdown:
groups multiple test cases (listed in Block) under a single Description quote.

Describes can be grouped under so-called *test groups*. Unless you provide a group (or several) yourself, the describe will belong to the test group called 'rogue'.

You can specify one or more groups the describe will belong to using `in`. The following describes are grouped under 'rogue':

```
describe 'Foo' [
  it should 'work' [ "..." ]
]

describe 'Bar' [
  it should 'a' [ "..." ]
  it should 'b' [ "..." ]
]
```

The following describes are grouped under 'foo':

```
describe 'Foo' [
  in foo

  it should 'work' [ "..." ]
]

describe 'Bar' [
  in foo

  it should 'a' [ "..." ]
  it should 'b' [ "..." ]
]
```

You can run a test group using the word `runTestsInGroup:`. It will run all tests and echo the test report to the standard output on the fly. With describes as above, that is, belonging to the group 'foo', you can run them like so:

```
runTestsInGroup: foo
```

Describes can belong to multiple groups:

```
describe 'Foo' [
  in a
  in b

  it should 'happy path' [ true true assert= ]
]

describe 'Bar' [
  in a

  it should 'sad path' [ true false assert= ]
]

runTestsInGroup: a  "runs Foo and Bar"
runTestsInGroup: b  "runs Foo"
```
words.primer: groups multiple test cases (listed in Block) under a single Description quote.

words.name: leaves:
words.markdown:
compares active stack with Block: noop if equal via `=`, otherwise, dies. Note that only N last items in active stack are compared with Block, where N is the amount of items in Block.

```
100 leaves: [ 100 ] "Stack has 100 now."
200 leaves: [ 100 200 ] "Stack has 100 and 200."
300 leaves: [ 300 ] "Stack has 100 and 200 and 300"
```
words.primer: compares active stack with Block: noop if equal via `=`, otherwise, dies.

words.name: sdl:keysym
words.markdown:
The SDL keysym structure, used in key events.

If you are looking for translated character input, see the `sdl:textInputEvent`.

- `scancode`: SDL physical key code (see `sdl:scancode:*`)
- `keycode`: SDL virtual key code.
- `mod`: current key modifiers.
words.primer: The SDL keysym structure, used in key events.

words.name: sdl:commonEvent
words.markdown:
Fields shared by every event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
words.primer: Fields shared by every event.

words.name: sdl:displayEvent
words.markdown:
Display state change event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `display`: the associated display index.
- `event`: one of `sdl:displayEvent:*`.
- `data1`: event dependent data.
words.primer: Display state change event.

words.name: sdl:windowEvent
words.markdown:
Window state change event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: the associated window.
- `event`: one of `sdl:windowEvent:*`.
- `data1`: event dependent data.
- `data2`: event dependent data.
words.primer: Window state change event.

words.name: sdl:keyboardEvent
words.markdown:
Keyboard button event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with keyboard focus, if any.
- `state`: `sdl:pressedState` or `sdl:releasedState`
- `repeat`: non-zero if this is a key repeat
- `event`: one of `sdl:windowEvent:*`.
- `keysym`: the key that was pressed or released, see `sdl:keysym`.
words.primer: Keyboard button event.

words.name: sdl:textEditingEvent
words.markdown:
Keyboard text editing event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with keyboard focus, if any.
- `text`: points to 32 `u8`s of the the editing text.
- `start`: the start cursor of selected editing text.
- `length`: the length of selected editing text.
words.primer: Keyboard text editing event.

words.name: sdl:textEditingEvent*
words.markdown:
Extended keyboard text editing event when text would be truncated if stored in the text buffer `sdl:textEditingEvent`.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with keyboard focus, if any.
- `text`: the editing text, which should be freed with `sdl:free`, and will not be NULL.
- `start`: the start cursor of selected editing text.
- `length`: the length of selected editing text.
words.primer: Extended keyboard text editing event when text would be truncated if stored in the text buffer `sdl:textEditingEvent`.

words.name: sdl:textInputEvent
words.markdown:
Keyboard text input event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with keyboard focus, if any.
- `text`: points to 32 `u8`s of the the editing text.
words.primer: Keyboard text input event.

words.name: sdl:mouseMotionEvent
words.markdown:
Mouse motion event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with mouse focus, if any.
- `which`: the mouse instance id, or `sdl:touchMouseId`
- `state`: the current button state (`sdl:pressedState` or `sdl:releasedState`).
- `x`: X coordinate, relative to window.
- `y`: Y coordinate, relative to window.
- `xrel`: The relative motion in the X direction.
- `yrel`: The relative motion in the Y direction.
words.primer: Mouse motion event.

words.name: sdl:mouseButtonEvent
words.markdown:
Mouse button event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with mouse focus, if any.
- `which`: the mouse instance id, or `sdl:touchMouseId`.
- `button`: the mouse button index.
- `state`: the current button state (`sdl:pressedState` or `sdl:releasedState`).
- `clicks`: 1 for single-click, 2 for double-click, etc.
- `x`: X coordinate, relative to window.
- `y`: Y coordinate, relative to window.
words.primer: Mouse button event.

words.name: sdl:mouseWheelEvent
words.markdown:
Mouse wheel event structure.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `windowID`: The window with mouse focus, if any.
- `which`: the mouse instance id, or `sdl:touchMouseId`.
- `x`: the amount scrolled horizontally, positive to the right and negative to the left.
- `y`: the amount scrolled vertically, positive away from the user and negative toward the user.
- `direction`: set to one of `sdl:mouseWheel:*`. When `sdl:mouseWheel:flipped`, the values in X and Y will be opposite. Multiply by -1 to change them back.
- `preciseX`: the amount scrolled horizontally, positive to the right and negative to the left, with float precision.
- `preciseY`: The amount scrolled vertically, positive away from the user and negative toward the user, with float precision.
- `mouseX`: X coordinate, relative to window.
- `mouseY`: Y coordinate, relative to window.
words.primer: Mouse wheel event structure.

words.name: sdl:dropEvent
words.markdown:
An event used to request a file open by the system. This event is enabled by default, you can disable it with `sdl:eventState`.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
- `file`: points to the file name, which should be freed with `sdl:free`. Is NULL on begin/complete.
- `windowID`: the window that was dropped on, if any.
words.primer: An event used to request a file open by the system.

words.name: sdl:quitEvent
words.markdown:
The "quit requested" event.

- `timestamp`: in milliseconds, populated using `sdl:ticks`.
words.primer: The "quit requested" event.

words.name: sdl:event
words.markdown:
General event structure.

* `type`: event type, shared with all events.

The following is a list of event types/fields that are implemented. Those that are simply `pointer`s are unimplemented.

- `common`: common event data (see `sdl:commonEvent`).
- `display`: display event data (see `sdl:displayEvent`).
- `window`: window event data (see `sdl:windowEvent`).
- `key`: keyboard event data (see `sdl:keyboardEvent`).
- `edit`: text editing event data (see `sdl:textEditingEvent`).
- `edit*`: extended text editing event data (see `sdl:textEditingEvent*`).
- `text`: text input event data (see `sdl:textInputEvent`).
- `motion`: mouse motion event data (see `sdl:mouseMotionEvent`).
- `button`: mouse button event data (see `sdl:mouseButtonEvent`).
- `wheel`: mouse wheel event data (see `sdl:mouseWheelEvent`).
- `quit`: quit request event data (see `sdl:quitEvent`).
- `drop`: drag and drop event data (see `sdl:dropEvent`).
words.primer: General event structure.

words.name: sdl:intPoint
words.markdown:
The structure that defines a point (integer).

- `x`: the X coordinate of the point.
- `y`: the Y coordinate of the point.
words.primer: The structure that defines a point (integer).

words.name: sdl:floatPoint
words.markdown:
The structure that defines a point (floating point).

- `x`: the X coordinate of the point.
- `y`: the Y coordinate of the point.
words.primer: The structure that defines a point (floating point).

words.name: sdl:intRect
words.markdown:
A rectangle, with the origin at the upper left (integer).

- `x`: the X coordinate of the rectangle.
- `y`: the Y coordinate of the rectangle.
- `w`: width of the rectangle.
- `h`: height of the rectangle.
words.primer: A rectangle, with the origin at the upper left (integer).

words.name: sdl:floatRect
words.markdown:
A rectangle, with the origin at the upper left (floating point).

- `x`: the X coordinate of the rectangle.
- `y`: the Y coordinate of the rectangle.
- `w`: width of the rectangle.
- `h`: height of the rectangle.
words.primer: A rectangle, with the origin at the upper left (floating point).

words.name: sdl:intRectsIntersect?
words.markdown: leaves whether the two integer Rectangles intersect. If either is null will leave 0.
words.primer: leaves whether the two integer Rectangles intersect.

words.name: sdl:floatRectsIntersect?
words.markdown: leaves whether the two floating point Rectangles intersect. If either is null will leave 0.
words.primer: leaves whether the two floating point Rectangles intersect.

words.name: sdl:writeIntRectIntersection?
words.markdown: calculate the intersection of two integer Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.
words.primer: calculate the intersection of two integer Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.

words.name: sdl:writeFloatRectIntersection?
words.markdown: calculate the intersection of two floating point Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.
words.primer: calculate the intersection of two floating point Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.

words.name: sdl:writeIntRectUnion?
words.markdown: calculate the union of two integer Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.
words.primer: calculate the union of two integer Rectangles and writes it into Result hole.

words.name: sdl:writeFloatRectUnion?
words.markdown: calculate the union of two floating point Rectangles and write it into Result hole.
words.primer: calculate the union of two floating point Rectangles and write it into Result hole.

words.name: sdl:color
words.markdown:
Represents a color.

- `r`: the red component in the range 0-255.
- `g`: the green component in the range 0-255.
- `b`: the blue component in the range 0-255.
- `a`: the alpha component in the range 0-255.
words.primer: Represents a color.

words.name: sdl:palette
words.markdown:
Palette information.

- `ncolors`: the number of colors in the palette.
- `colors`: an array of `sdl:color`s representing the palette.
words.primer: Palette information.

words.name: sdl:pixelFormat
words.markdown:
Pixel format information. Everything is read-only.

- `format`: one of `sdl:pixelFormat:*`
- `palette`: an `sdl:palette` structure associated with this pixel format, or null if the format doesn't have a palette.
- `bitsPerPixel`: the number of significant bits in a pixel value, e.g.: 8, 15, 16, 24, 32.
- `bytesPerPixel`: the number of bytes required to hold a pixel value, e.g.: 1, 2, 3, 4.
- `rmask`: a mask representing the location of the red component of the pixel.
- `gmask`: a mask representing the location of the green component of the pixel.
- `bmask`: a mask representing the location of the blue component of the pixel.
- `amask`: a mask representing the location of the alpha component of the pixel or 0 if the pixel format doesn't have any alpha information.
words.primer: Pixel format information.

words.name: sdl:surface
words.markdown:
A collection of pixels used in software blitting.

- Read-only `format`: the format of the pixels stored in the surface. See `sdl:pixelFormat`.
- Read-only `w`, `h`: the width and height in pixels.
- Read-only `pitch`: the length of a row of pixels in bytes.
- Read-write `pixels`: the pointer to the actual pixel data.
- Read-write `userdata`: an arbitrary pointer you can set.
- Read-only `clipRect`: an `sdl:intRect` structure used to clip blits to the surface. Can be set by `sdl:setClipRect`.
words.primer: A collection of pixels used in software blitting.

words.name: sdl:init
words.markdown:
initializes the SDL library given subsystem initialization Flags. Leaves 0 on success or a negative error code on failure; use `sdl:error` for more information.

# Init flags

The following Flags are available.

- `sdl:init:timer`: timer subsystem
- `sdl:init:audio`: audio subsystem
- `sdl:init:video`: video subsystem; automatically initializes the events subsystem
- `sdl:init:joystick`: joystick subsystem; automatically initializes the events subsystem
- `sdl:init:haptic`: haptic (force feedback) subsystem
- `sdl:init:gameController`: controller subsystem; automatically initializes the joystick subsystem
- `sdl:init:events`: events subsystem
- `sdl:init:everything`: all of the above subsystems
- `sdl:init:noParachute`: compatibility; this flag is ignored
words.primer: initializes the SDL library given subsystem initialization Flags.

words.name: sdl:deinit
words.markdown:
shuts down specific SDL subsystems given any of the Flags used by `sdl:init`.

You still need to call `sdl:quit` even if you close all open subsystems with `sdl:deinit`.
words.primer: shuts down specific SDL subsystems given any of the Flags used by `sdl:init`.

words.name: sdl:createWindow
words.effect: ( T X Y W H F -- P ):
words.markdown:
creates a window and leaves a Pointer to it (or null if there was an error).

The window is created with the given Title, at the specified X and Y coordinates (these can also be set to `sdl:window:centered` or `sdl:window:positionUndefined`), with the specified Width and Height (in screen coordinates), and according to Flags.

## Window flags

The following Flags are available. They can be combined using `bit:or`, for example `sdl:window:resizable sdl:window:alwaysOnTop bit:or`.

- `sdl:window:fullscreen`: fullscreen window
- `sdl:window:opengl`: window usable with OpenGL context
- `sdl:window:shown`: window should be visible
- `sdl:window:hidden`: window should not be visible
- `sdl:window:borderless`: no window decoration
- `sdl:window:resizable`: window can be resized
- `sdl:window:minimized`: window should be minimized
- `sdl:window:maximized`: window should be maximized
- `sdl:window:mouseGrabbed`: window has grabbed mouse input
- `sdl:window:inputFocus`: window has input focus
- `sdl:window:mouseFocus`: window has mouse focus
- `sdl:window:fullscreenDesktop`: fullscreen window at the current desktop resolution
- `sdl:window:foreign`: window not created by SDL
- `sdl:window:allowHighDPI`: window should be created in high-DPI mode if supported
- `sdl:window:mouseCapture`: window has mouse captured (unrelated to `sdl:window:mouseGrabbed`)
- `sdl:window:alwaysOnTop`: window should always be above others
- `sdl:window:skipTaskbar`: window should not be added to the taskbar
- `sdl:window:utility`: window should be treated as a utility window
- `sdl:window:tooltip`: window should be treated as a tooltip
- `sdl:window:popupMenu`: window should be treated as a popup menu
- `sdl:window:keyboardGrabbed`: window has grabbed keyboard input
- `sdl:window:vulkan`: window usable for Vulkan surface
- `sdl:window:metal`: window usable for Metal view
words.primer: creates a window and leaves a Pointer to it (or null if there was an error).

words.name: sdl:createRenderer
words.markdown:
creates a 2D rendering context for a Window pointer and leaves a pointer to it (or null if there was an error).

Window pointer is a pointer to the window where rendering is displayed.

Index is the index of the rendering driver to initialize, or -1 to initialize the first one supporting the requested flags.

Flags is one or more of the following flags, you can use `bit:or` to combine them.

- `sdl:renderer:software`: the renderer is a software fallback
- `sdl:renderer:accelerated`: the renderer uses hardware acceleration
- `sdl:renderer:presentVsync`: present is synchronized with the refresh rate
- `sdl:renderer:targetTexture`: the renderer supports rendering to texture
words.primer: creates a 2D rendering context for a Window pointer and leaves a pointer to it (or null if there was an error).

words.name: sdl:ensure
words.markdown:
dies with `sdl:error` if Status is negative.

Some SDL and SDL TTF functions return negative integers to signal an error. In this case, this word will die preventing the following code to be executed, so you don't have to worry about handling SDl errors.

Note that by dying you may cause some resources to *not* be freed. Keeping track of that is a task for a higher- level wrapper around these bingings. This word nor any word that is part of these bindings won't do anything about it.
words.primer: dies with `sdl:error` if Status is negative.

words.name: sdl:notNull
words.markdown:
dies if Pointer is NULL, that is, if Pointer is equal to `0`.

Novika uses decimals to represent pointers, which is unsafe but OK for such low-level code. This word allows you to catch and die on NULLs rather than handling them explicitly, which is a bit more tedious.

Note that by dying you may cause some resources to *not* be freed. Keeping track of that is a task for a higher- level wrapper around these bingings. This word nor any word that is part of these bindings won't do anything about it.
words.primer: dies if Pointer is NULL, that is, if Pointer is equal to `0`.

words.name: sdl:ttf:init
words.markdown:
initializes the truetype font API.

Must be called before using other functions in this library, except `sdl:ttf:init?`. SDL does not have to be initialized before this call.

Leaves 0 if initialization was successful or -1 if an error occured. Use `sdl:error` to get a human-readable error message for this word and for words in this library which leave 0/-1 to signal an error.
words.primer: initializes the truetype font API.

words.name: sdl:ttf:quit
words.markdown:
shuts down and cleans up the truetype font API.

After calling this the `sdl:ttf` library functions should not be used, except for `sdl:ttf:init?`. You may, of course, use `sdl:ttf:init` to use the functionality again.
words.primer: shuts down and cleans up the truetype font API.

words.name: sdl:ttf:open
words.markdown:
loads and leaves Font pointer from the provided File name, uses the given Point size. The latter basically translates to pixel height.

Leaves NULL (0) on error.
words.primer: loads and leaves Font pointer from the provided File name, uses the given Point size.

words.name: sdl:ttf:close
words.markdown: free the memory used by font at Foint pointer, and free font itself as well. Do not use font after this without loading a new font to it.
words.primer: free the memory used by font at Foint pointer, and free font itself as well.

words.name: sdl:ttf:putSize
words.markdown:
calculates the resulting surface size of Quote rendered using the font behind Font pointer. Width is put into Width hole, and height is put into Height hole.

Consider using `sdl:ttf:size` which create and read from the holes for you.
words.primer: calculates the resulting surface size of Quote rendered using the font behind Font pointer.

words.name: sdl:ttf:getSolidSurface
words.markdown: renders Quote painted with Foreground `sdl:color` using font behind Font pointer. Leaves Surface pointer to a new surface containing the rendered quote, *which you must free when it becomes unused*.
words.primer: renders Quote painted with Foreground `sdl:color` using font behind Font pointer.

words.name: sdl:ttf:getShadedSurface
words.markdown:
renders Quote painted with Foreground color (an `sdl:color~`) with background of Background color (also an `sdl:color~`), using font behind Font pointer. Leaves Surface pointer to a new surface containing the rendered quote, *which you must free when it becomes unused*.

Slower but sharper than `sdl:ttf:getSolidSurface`.
words.primer: renders Quote painted with Foreground color (an `sdl:color~`) with background of Background color (also an `sdl:color~`), using font behind Font pointer.

words.name: sdl:ttf:getBlendedSurface
words.markdown:
renders Quote painted with Foreground color (an `sdl:color~`), using font behind Font pointer. Leaves Surface pointer to a new surface containing the rendered quote, *which you must free when it becomes unused*.

The sharpest but slowest way to render text. Text is blended with whatever is behind.
words.primer: renders Quote painted with Foreground color (an `sdl:color~`), using font behind Font pointer.

words.primer: calculates and leaves Width and Height of Quote rendered using the font behind Font pointer.

appends Form with foreground and background colors swapped with each other (background color is set to foreground color, and vice versa).

Note: if unsupported by the output stream, will print Form as-is.

words.name: withEmphasisAppendEcho

words.name: withColorAppendEcho
words.markdown:
appends Form with last color from the echo foreground color stack set as foreground color, and last color from the echo background stack set as background color, to the standard output stream.

Note: some implementations (particularly Novika's default implementation) choose to restrict foreground and background colors to system's basic 16 colors for compatibility & portability. If you want more cross-platform control over colors (and pretty much everything else), take a look at console capability.
words.primer: appends Form with last color from the echo foreground color stack set as foreground color, and last color from the echo background stack set as background color, to the standard output stream.

words.primer: enquotes and appends Form to the standard output stream.

words.name: readLine
words.markdown:
enquotes and prints Prompt form to the standard output stream. Waits for the user to answer, enquotes the answer and leaves it.

If user answered the prompt, leaves Answer quote followed by boolean true. Otherwise, leaves boolean false.

```
'What is your name? ' readLine => echo

"INPUT: What is your name? John Doe⏎"
"STDOUT: John Doe⏎"

"INPUT: What is your name? <Ctrl-D>"
"[Program exits]"
```
words.primer: enquotes and prints Prompt form to the standard output stream.

words.name: readLine*
words.markdown:
extended (contextful) version of `readLine`. Accepts Configuration block and leaves Answer quote followed by `true`, otherwise, if the prompt was rejected, leaves just `false`.

## Configuring the prompt

To configure the prompt you should create a Configuration block and populate it with settings according to how you want the prompt to look like and work.

### Empty or meaningless configuration block

If you pass an empty Configuration block or one that has no entries that are of interest to `readLine*`, then you will get an empty prompt but a prompt nonetheless (i.e. everything will work fine; *all of the settings below are opt-in*).

### Available settings

#### `prompt`

`prompt` allows you to assign the prompt quote. In case it is an opener entry it will be opened like so: `( L -- Pq )` where P is the prompt quote and L is the line number (because multiline editing is supported). So you can set custom prompts for every line, or use only one for all of them.

```
[ '>>> ' $: prompt ] obj readLine*

"""
>>> example inp|ut

>>> example multiline
>>> inp|ut
"""

[ [ 1 = sel: '>>> ' '... ' ] @: prompt ] readLine*

"""
>>> example multiline
... inp|ut
"""
```

#### `history`

If Configuration block has a `history` entry (a quote), then history is going to be saved to, and loaded from that entry.

If there is no `history` entry in the Configuration block, then history is not going to be persisted.

```
[ ('>>> ' $: prompt) ('' $: history) ] obj $: config

loop: [
  config readLine* or: break

  [
    'h' [ config.history echo ]
    [ ] [ echo ]
  ] choose
]

"Do something with the history after the loop breaks..."

'History after the loop: ' config.history 2echo
```

#### `more?`

`more?` allows to specify whether more of the input should be expected, that is, if the prompt should continue on another line.

By default it is `false`, and is expected to be boolean `false` or anything else (interpreted as `true`). If `more?` is an opener, it is expected to be compatible with the following signature: `( Paq -- true / false )`, where Paq is the partial answer quote. If the block leaves anything other than `true` or `false`, that is interpreted as `true`.

```
[ [ 1 = sel: '>>> ' '... ' ] @: prompt

  [ orphan swap

    false $: result "< Don't need anything else..."

    [ "Oops, probably 'slurp' died, so let's try to wait
       for enough input to not make slurp die..."
      true =: result
    ] @: __died__

    slurp "Regardless of whether `slurp` dies, we end up here" result
  ] @: more?
] obj $: config

'Enter parseable Novika code or I will go multiline:' echo

loop: [ config readLine* br: echo break ]
```

#### `delimiters`

`delimiters` is a quote (or a block that leaves a quote in case `delimiters` is an opener entry) that lists *word delimiter* characters, useful for jumping through words and autocompletion.

```
[ ('Enter your name> ' $: prompt) (' .,-' $: delimiters) ] obj $: config

config readLine* or: okbye $: name

[ 'Your name is: ' name ] ~* echo
```

#### `suggest`

If `suggest` is a pusher entry, it should be a block of the following shape: `[ title [ ...suggestion ] ]`, where `title` and every one of `suggestion`s are quotes.

`title` followed by colon ':' is displayed above the list of suggestions. The list can be opened using the Tab key, escaped from using Escape.

```
[ 'Enter your name> ' $: prompt

  [ 'Possible names'
    [ 'John'
      'Alice'
      'Mary'
      'David' ]
  ] $: suggest
] obj $: config

config readLine*
```

In case `suggest` is an opener, it is expected to be compatible with the following signature: `( P W -- Tq Sb )` where W is the current word (as per `delimiters`), P is the prior quote (all that precedes W), Tq is the title quote, and Sb is the suggestions block.

```
[ 'Enter expression> ' $: prompt

  ' ' $: delimiters

  [ $: word $: prior

    'Possible evaluations (+, -, *)'

    [ [ ] prior slurp [+] 0 reduce
      [ ] prior slurp [-] 0 reduce
      [ ] prior slurp [*] 1 reduce
    ] vals
  ] @: suggest
] obj $: config

config readLine*
```
words.primer: extended (contextful) version of `readLine`.

words.name: reportError
words.markdown:
reports about an error to the standard error stream, given an Error object.

You can obtain an error object by, e.g., catching it in `__died__`.
words.primer: reports about an error to the standard error stream, given an Error object.

words.name: monotonic
words.markdown:
leaves a Reading from the monotonic clock to measure elapsed time, in milliseconds.

Values from the monotonic clock and wall clock are not comparable. Monotonic clock should be independent from discontinuous jumps in the system time, such as leap seconds, time zone adjustments or manual changes to the computer's clock.

```
monotonic $: start
20 nap
monotonic $: end
end start - echo
"STDOUT: 20⏎ (approximately)"
```
words.primer: leaves a Reading from the monotonic clock to measure elapsed time, in milliseconds.

words.name: nap
words.markdown: sleeps a Duration of time, given in *milliseconds*.
words.primer: sleeps a Duration of time, given in *milliseconds*.

words.name: bye
words.markdown: ends the program with the given decimal Exit code.
words.primer: ends the program with the given decimal Exit code.

words.name: bit:fromLeft
words.markdown:
leaves Index-th Bit from left in the given Decimal, represented as `0` or `1`. Dies if Decimal has a fractional part. The sign of decimal is ignored.

Note: we consider the *left*most bit to be the most significant bit, and the *right*most bit the least significant bit. Leading zeroes do not count.

```
0b00010001 0 bit:fromLeft leaves: 1
0b00010001 1 bit:fromLeft leaves: 0
0b00010001 2 bit:fromLeft leaves: 0
0b00010001 3 bit:fromLeft leaves: 0
0b00010001 4 bit:fromLeft leaves: 1
```
words.primer: leaves Index-th Bit from left in the given Decimal, represented as `0` or `1`.

words.name: bit:fromRight
words.markdown:
leaves Index-th Bit from right in the given Decimal, represented as `0` or `1`. Dies if Decimal has a fractional part. The sign of decimal is ignored.

Note: we consider the *left*most bit to be the most significant bit, and the *right*most bit the least significant bit. Leading zeroes do not count.

```
0b00010001 0 bit:fromRight leaves: 1
0b00010001 1 bit:fromRight leaves: 0
0b00010001 2 bit:fromRight leaves: 0
0b00010001 3 bit:fromRight leaves: 0
0b00010001 4 bit:fromRight leaves: 1
```
words.primer: leaves Index-th Bit from right in the given Decimal, represented as `0` or `1`.

words.name: bit:count
words.markdown:
leaves Bit count, the number of bits in the given Decimal. Dies if Decimal has a fractional part.

```
0b00010001 bit:count leaves: 4
```
words.primer: leaves Bit count, the number of bits in the given Decimal.

words.name: bit:or
words.markdown:
combines two Decimal numbers using bitwise or, leaves the resulting Decimal. Dies if either of decimal has a fractional part.

```
0b00010001
0b10001000 bit:or leaves:
0b10011001
```
words.primer: combines two Decimal numbers using bitwise or, leaves the resulting Decimal.

words.name: bit:and
words.markdown:
combines two Decimal numbers using bitwise and, leaves the resulting Decimal. Dies if either of decimal has a fractional part.

```
0b10011001
0b00011000 bit:and leaves:
0b00011000
```
words.primer: combines two Decimal numbers using bitwise and, leaves the resulting Decimal.

words.name: bit:bits
words.markdown:
leaves Bits block for the given Decimal, which contains the binary representation of the *absolute value* of Decimal, starting with the most-significant bit.

```
0b10011001 bit:bits leaves: [ 1 0 0 1 1 0 0 1 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Bits block for the given Decimal, which contains the binary representation of the *absolute value* of Decimal, starting with the most-significant bit.

words.name: bit:fromBits
words.markdown:
converts Bits block to a Decimal. Bits block should contain binary digits (represented by `0` or `1`), and should begin with the most significant bit.

```
0b10011001 bit:bits leaves: [[ 1 0 0 1 1 0 0 1 ]]
           bit:fromBits leaves: 0b10011001
```
words.primer: converts Bits block to a Decimal.

words.name: rgb
words.markdown:
creates a Color form from three decimals Red (0-255), Green (0-255), and Blue (0-255).

```
36 255 255 rgb toQuote leaves: 'rgb(36, 255 ,255)'
```'
```
words.primer: creates a Color form from three decimals Red (0-255), Green (0-255), and Blue (0-255).

words.name: getRGB
words.markdown:
leaves Red, Green, Blue values for a Color form.

```
0 25 3 rgb "rgb(0, 25, 3)" getRGB leaves: [ 0 25 3 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Red, Green, Blue values for a Color form.

words.name: hsl
words.markdown:
creates a Color form from three decimals Hue (0-360, degrees), Saturation (0-100, percents), Lightness (0-100, percents).

Since color forms are stored in RGB, the HSL color is first converted into RGB.

```
206 35 46 hsl toQuote leaves: 'rgb(76, 123, 158)'
```
words.primer: creates a Color form from three decimals Hue (0-360, degrees), Saturation (0-100, percents), Lightness (0-100, percents).

words.name: getHSL
words.markdown:
leaves Hue, Saturation, Lightness for a Color form.

```
206 35 46 hsl "rgb(76, 123, 158)" getHSL leaves: [ 206 35 46 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Hue, Saturation, Lightness for a Color form.

words.name: hsv
words.markdown:
creates a Color form from three decimals Hue (0-360, degrees), Saturation (0-100, percents), Value (0-100, percents).

Since color forms are stored in RGB, the HSV color is first converted into RGB.

```
120 100 100 hsv toQuote leaves: 'rgb(0, 255, 0)'
```
words.primer: creates a Color form from three decimals Hue (0-360, degrees), Saturation (0-100, percents), Value (0-100, percents).

words.name: getHSV
words.markdown:
leaves Hue, Saturation, Value for a Color form.

```
180 100 50 hsv "rgb(0,128,128)" getHSV leaves: [ 180 100 50 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Hue, Saturation, Value for a Color form.

words.name: lch
words.markdown:
creates a Color form from three decimals Lightness (0-100), Chroma (0-132), Hue (0-360).

Since color forms are stored as RGB, the LCH color is first converted into RGB.

LCH colors are tricky to implement but very fun to use. That's why they're in Novika's standard library.

CIELAB encloses more colors than sRGB, so some conversion imprecisions *are* to be expected because some colors just fall out of sRGB gamut (lossiness is especially noticeable in LCH -> RGB -> LCH conversions, but it stabilizes on the last step because the last step's LCH is guraranteed to be inside the sRGB gamut).

Any color out of the sRGB gamut is brought into the sRGB gamut by lowering chroma until it's in the sRGB bounds.

Here is a 'good' conversion, meaning it nicely closes on itself:

```
78 74 133 lch $: color

color toQuote leaves: 'rgb(122, 215, 85)'
color getLCH leaves: [ 78 74 133 ]
color getLCH lch toQuote leaves: 'rgb(122, 215, 85)''
"And so on..."
```

And here is a bad conversion. At first, though, for it does stabilize after a few rounds as it falls firmly into the sRGB color space.

```
74 107 26 lch $: color
color toQuote leaves: 'rgb(255, 154, 151)'

"Note how many chroma units we lose! Plus, Lab and
 LCH have hue shift on chroma changes, hence 26 -> 25."
color getLCH leaves: [ 74 41 25 ]

color getLCH lch toQuote leaves: 'rgb(255, 154, 152)'

color getLCH lch getLCH leaves: [ 74 41 25 ]
"... and so on, conversion had stabilized ..."
```

You don't necessarily have to think about this, because the resulting colors do look very similar, differing in points rather than magnitudes. Just be aware that the conversion method used by this word and `getLCH` is lossy in some cases.
words.primer: creates a Color form from three decimals Lightness (0-100), Chroma (0-132), Hue (0-360).

words.name: getLCH
words.markdown:
leaves Lightness, Chroma, Hue for a Color form. Please read documentation for `lch` to understand why `a b c lch getLCH` might not leave `a b c`.

```
78 74 133 lch toQuote leaves: 'rgb(122, 215, 85)'
78 74 133 lch getLCH leaves: [ 78 74 133 ]

74 107 26 lch toQuote leaves: 'rgb(255, 154, 152)'

"Chroma lowered to fit into sRGB. Lab and LCH have hue
 shift on chroma changes, 26 -> 25"
74 107 26 lch getLCH leaves: [ 74 41 25 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Lightness, Chroma, Hue for a Color form.

words.name: withAlpha
words.markdown:
leaves Color form with alpha channel set to Alpha (0-255).

```
0 25 3 rgb toQuote leaves: 'rgb(0, 25, 3)'
0 25 3 rgb 100 withAlpha toQuote leaves: 'rgba(0, 25, 3, 100)'
```
words.primer: leaves Color form with alpha channel set to Alpha (0-255).

words.name: getAlpha
words.markdown:
leaves Alpha for the given Color form.

```
0 25 3 rgb getAlpha leaves: 255 "Opaque = 255"
0 25 3 rgb 100 withAlpha getAlpha leaves: 100
```
words.primer: leaves Alpha for the given Color form.

words.name: fromPalette
words.markdown:
leaves the Closest color form to Color from a Palette block. How close the color is is determined by distance: the Closest color is that color in Palette block to which Color has least (minimum) distance.

```
[ 0 0 0 rgb
  255 0 0 rgb
  0 255 0 rgb
  0 0 255 rgb
  255 255 255 rgb
] vals $: pal

0 0 0 rgb pal fromPalette toQuote leaves: 'rgb(0, 0, 0)'
76 175 80 rgb pal fromPalette "greenish" toQuote leaves: 'rgb(0, 255, 0)'
220 237 200 rgb pal fromPalette "very light green" toQuote leaves: 'rgb(255, 255, 255)'
74 20 140 rgb pal fromPalette "very dark purple" toQuote leaves: 'rgb(255, 0, 0)'
```
words.primer: leaves the Closest color form to Color from a Palette block.

words.markdown: leaves the Prototype block of Block.
words.primer: leaves the Prototype block of Block.

words.markdown: leaves the Parent block of Block.
words.primer: leaves the Parent block of Block.

words.primer: leaves pointer Address of Block.

words.primer: creates a Continuation from a Stack and a Block.

words.primer: leaves the Code block of a Continuation.
