words.primer: leaves the Stack block of a Continuation.

words.name: this
words.markdown:
pushes the Block it's opened in.

```
[ this ] open echo
"STDOUT: [ this ]⏎ (instance of `[ this ]`)"
```
words.primer: pushes the Block it's opened in.

words.name: stack
words.markdown:
pushes the Stack it's opened in.

```
stack dup echo
"STDOUT: [ ⭮ ]⏎"

'foo' <<
stack echo
"STDOUT: [ ⭮ 'foo' ]⏎"
```
words.primer: pushes the Stack it's opened in.

words.name: ahead
words.markdown:
leaves the block that will be executed after `this` finishes.

```
100 [ ahead 1 inject ] open + leaves: 101 "(i.e. 100 1 +)"
```
words.primer: leaves the block that will be executed after `this` finishes.

words.name: resume
words.markdown: closes blocks all the way up to, but not including, Block.
words.primer: closes blocks all the way up to, but not including, Block.

words.name: dup
words.markdown:
duplicates the Form before cursor.

```
'hello' dup leaves: [ 'hello' 'hello' ]

[ 1 2 | 3 ] $: block
block [ dup ] hydrate
block leaves: [ [ 1 2 2 | 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: duplicates the Form before cursor.

words.name: drop
words.markdown:
drops the Form before cursor.

```
'hello' drop leaves: [ ]

[ 1 2 | 3 ] $: block
block [ drop ] hydrate
block leaves: [ [ 1 | 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: drops the Form before cursor.

words.name: swap
words.markdown:
swaps two Forms before cursor.

```
1 2 swap leaves: [ 2 1 ]

[ 1 2 | 3 ] $: block
block [ swap ] hydrate
block leaves: [ [ 2 1 | 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: swaps two Forms before cursor.

words.name: hydrate
words.markdown: opens (evaluates) Form with Stack set as the active stack. If Form is not a block, it is added to Stack (equivalent to `<<`), If Form is a block, its instance is opened. To open a block without creating an instance of it (unsafe), use `hydrate!`.
words.primer: opens (evaluates) Form with Stack set as the active stack.

words.name: hydrate!
words.markdown:
opens (evaluates) Form with Stack set as the active stack. If Form is not a block, the behavior is the same as in `hydrate`. If Form is a block, performs unsafe hydration (hydrates without making an instance of the block). For a safer alternative, see `hydrate`. Use if you know what you're doing, or if you're ready to make an instance yourself.

Details: `hydrate!` is considered unsafe because hydration artifacts are exposed to the user and/or its blocks. The contents of a block after hydration may differ from its contents before unsafe hydration. Indeed, `hydrate!` is almost as unsafe as pushing into `conts`; the only benefit it provides is that it is able to catch infinite/very deep recursion.
words.primer: opens (evaluates) Form with Stack set as the active stack.

words.name: open
words.markdown:
opens Form in the active stack. Equivalent to `stack F hydrate`.

```
100 open leaves: 100

1 [ 2 + ] open leaves: 3
```
words.primer: opens Form in the active stack.

words.name: there
words.markdown:
opens Block with Stack set as the active stack. Leaves Stack. Ahead is transferred to block.

```
[ 1 2 ] [ + ] there leaves: [ [ 3 ] ]
[ 1 2 ] [ ahead thruBlock open ] there + leaves: [ [ 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: opens Block with Stack set as the active stack.

words.name: do
words.markdown:
opens Form with an empty stack activated, and disposed when Form has been evaluated.

```
[ 'Hi!' echo ] do
"STDOUT: Hi!⏎"
```
words.primer: opens Form with an empty stack activated, and disposed when Form has been evaluated.

words.name: new
words.markdown: leaves an Instance of a Block.
words.primer: leaves an Instance of a Block.

words.name: shallowNew
words.markdown:
leaves a Shallow instance of Block.

`shallowNew` is different from `new` in that it does not reparent sub-blocks to the parent instance recursively. Instead, it only creates an instance of Block, and does not look at skips its content entirely.

```
[ $: x [ x ] ] @: newBox

1 newBox $: fooBox1
2 newBox $: fooBox2
3 newBox $: fooBox3

fooBox1 open leaves: 1
fooBox2 open leaves: 2
fooBox3 open leaves: 3

[ fooBox1 fooBox2 fooBox3 ] vals $: boxes

boxes shallowNew $: shallowBoxesInstance
shallowBoxesInstance 0 fromLeft open leaves: 1
shallowBoxesInstance 1 fromLeft open leaves: 2
shallowBoxesInstance 2 fromLeft open leaves: 3

"Works as expected! Note that sub-blocks are exactly the same as
 those in the original 'boxes' block. However, 'shallowBoxesInstance'
 and 'boxes' are different blocks now:"

(shallowBoxesInstance 0 fromLeft) (boxes 0 fromLeft) same? leaves: true
(shallowBoxesInstance 1 fromLeft) (boxes 1 fromLeft) same? leaves: true
(shallowBoxesInstance 2 fromLeft) (boxes 2 fromLeft) same? leaves: true

boxes shallowBoxesInstance same? leaves: false

"... and 'shallowBoxesInstance' does indeed have 'boxes' as its parent:"

(shallowBoxesInstance parent) boxes same? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves a Shallow instance of Block.

words.name: sel
words.markdown: selects A (Determiner is truthy) or B (Determiner is falsey)
words.primer: selects A (Determiner is truthy) or B (Determiner is falsey)

words.name: br
words.markdown: opens True/False forms depending on Determiner being true/false.
words.primer: opens True/False forms depending on Determiner being true/false.

words.markdown: leaves whether A is smaller than (less than) B.
words.primer: leaves whether A is smaller than (less than) B.

words.name: same?
words.markdown:
leaves whether two Forms are the same (by reference for block, by value for any other form).

```
1 2 same? leaves: false
1 1 same? leaves: true

'hello' 'hello world' same? leaves: false
'hello' 'hello' same? leaves: true

"etc..."

[ 1 2 + ] $: b1
[ 1 2 + ] $: b2

b1 b2 same? leaves: false "They're different blocks, content doesn't matter!"

b1 b1 same? leaves: true
b2 b2 same? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether two Forms are the same (by reference for block, by value for any other form).

words.markdown:
leaves whether two Forms are equal by content (they may or may not be the same forms reference-wise, i.e., those for which `same?` would leave true).

```
1 2 = leaves: false
1 1 = leaves: true

'hello' 'hello world' = leaves: false
'hello' 'hello' = leaves: true

"etc..."

[ 1 2 + ] $: b1
[ 1 2 + ] $: b2

b1 b2 = leaves: true "They're equal by content!"

b1 b1 = leaves: true
b2 b2 = leaves: true

"Supports self-reference:"
[ ] $: b3
b3 b3 shove
b3 b3 = leaves: true
(b3 first) b3 = leaves: true
"etc..."
```
words.primer: leaves whether two Forms are equal by content (they may or may not be the same forms reference-wise, i.e., those for which `same?` would leave true).

words.name: anyof?
words.markdown:
leaves whether any form in Block is equal (via `=`) to Form.

```
1 [ 1 2 3 ] anyof? leaves: true
'hello' [ 'hello' 'world' 1 ] anyof? leaves: true
'hello' [ 1 2 3 ] anyof? leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether any form in Block is equal (via `=`) to Form.

words.name: occurrences
words.markdown:
leaves Begin indices of all occurrences of Pattern form/Pattern quote in Block/Quote. Begin indices is an orphan with no entries.

Works in a similar way to `anyof?` in that it compares each element of the Block/Quote with Pattern form/Pattern quote like `=` (but not using `=`, at least in the quote case where KMP is used).

```
[ ] 123 occurrences leaves: [ [ ] ]

[ 1 1 2 0 0 1 2 1 3 4 8 ] $: haystack
haystack 0 occurrences leaves: [ [ 3 4 ] ]
haystack 1 occurrences leaves: [ [ 0 1 5 7 ] ]
haystack 'foo' occurrences leaves: [ [ ] ]

'' 'foobar' occurrences leaves: [ [ ] ]
'foobar' '' occurrences leaves: [ [ ] ]

'foobra' $: haystack
haystack 'o' occurrences leaves: [ [ 1 2 ] ]
haystack 'foo' occurrences leaves: [ [ 0 ] ]
haystack 'ra' occurrences leaves: [ [ 4 ] ]

'GATCCATATG' $: haystack
haystack 'ATAAT' occurrences leaves: [ [ ] ]
haystack 'ATAT' occurrences leaves: [ [ 5 ] ]
```
words.primer: leaves Begin indices of all occurrences of Pattern form/Pattern quote in Block/Quote.

words.name: uppercase?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Quote is all-uppercase. If Quote is empty, leaves false.

```
'' uppercase? leaves: false
'A' uppercase? leaves: true
'hello' uppercase? leaves: false
'Hello' uppercase? leaves: false
'HELLO' uppercase? leaves: true
'HELLO WORLD' uppercase? leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether Quote is all-uppercase.

words.name: toUppercase
words.markdown:
leaves all- Uppercase quote for Quote: converts lowercase character(s) in Quote to uppercase. If Quote is empty, leaves empty quote.

```
'' toUppercase leaves: ''
'hello' toUppercase leaves: 'HELLO'
'hello world' toUppercase? leaves: 'HELLO WORLD'
```
words.primer: leaves all- Uppercase quote for Quote: converts lowercase character(s) in Quote to uppercase.

words.name: block?
words.markdown: leaves whether Form is a block.
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a block.

words.name: asBlock
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Block, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asBlock
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
[] asBlock leaves: [ [] "(the same block)" ]
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Block, dies if it's not.

words.name: word?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a word form, or a block that implements '**word**'.

```
#foo word? leaves: true

[ #foo $: __word__ this ] open word? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a word form, or a block that implements '**word**'.

words.name: private?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Word is private (by convention).

A Word prefixed by one or more underscores '_' *but that which does not end with one(s)* is considered private by convention. Hook words such as `__quote__` are *not* considered private.

The fact that privacy is defined "by convention" means that nothing actually stops anyone from obtaining the word's associated value form.

```
#hello private? leaves: false
#_hello private? leaves: true
#_ private? leaves: false "Beware!"
```
words.primer: leaves whether Word is private (by convention).

words.name: toWord
words.markdown:
converts Form into Word.

1. If Form is a word, behaves as noop
2. If Form is a quote, dies only if quote contains Unicode whitespace characters or is itself empty.
3. If Form is a quoted word, peels off **all** quoting
words.primer: converts Form into Word.

words.name: asWord
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Word form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asWord
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
#foo asWord leaves: [ foo ]
```

`__word__` hook can make a block usable in place of a word, provided its definition leaves a word or a block which implements '**word**':

```
[ $: x x $: __word__ this ] @: a
#foo a asWord "beware: leaves instance of a"
#boo a a asWord "beware: leaves instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Word form, dies if it's not.

words.name: quotedWord?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a quoted word form, or a block that implements '**quotedWord**'.

```
##foo quotedWord? leaves: true
[ ##foo $: __quotedWord__ this ] open quotedWord? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a quoted word form, or a block that implements '**quotedWord**'.

words.name: asQuotedWord
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Quoted word form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asQuotedWord
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
##foo asQuotedWord leaves: #foo
```

`__quotedWord__` hook can make a block usable in place of a quoted word, provided its definition leaves a quoted word or a block that implements `__quotedWord__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __quotedWord__ this ] @: a
##foo a asQuotedWord "beware: leaves instance of a"
##boo a a asQuotedWord "beware: leaves instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Quoted word form, dies if it's not.

words.name: decimal?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a decimal form, or a block that implements '**decimal**'.

```
123 decimal? leaves: true
[ 123 $: __decimal__ this ] open decimal? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a decimal form, or a block that implements '**decimal**'.

words.name: toQuotedWord
words.markdown:
adds a layer of "quoting" to Quoted word or Word.

```
"Note that in quoted word literals (here on the left hand
 side) one layer of quoting is 'eaten off' by the parser!"

#foo toQuotedWord leaves: #foo
##foo toQuotedWord leaves: ##foo
```
words.primer: adds a layer of "quoting" to Quoted word or Word.

words.name: asDecimal
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Decimal form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
'foo' asDecimal
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
100 asDecimal leaves: 100
```

`__decimal__` hook can make a block usable in place of a decimal, provided its definition leaves a decimal or a block that implements `__decimal__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __decimal__ this ] @: a
100 a asDecimal "beware: leaves an instance of a"
200 a a asDecimal "beware: leaves an instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Decimal form, dies if it's not.

words.name: quote?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a quote form, or a block that implements '**quote**'.

```
'foo' quote? leaves: true
[ 'foo' $: __quote__ this ] open quote? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a quote form, or a block that implements '**quote**'.

words.name: asQuote
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Quote form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asQuote
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
'foo' asQuote leaves: 'foo'
```

`__quote__` hook can make a block usable in place of a quote, provided its definition leaves a quote or a block that implements `__quote__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __quote__ this ] @: a
'foo' a asQuote "beware: leaves instance of a"
'boo' a a asQuote "beware: leaves instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Quote form, dies if it's not.

words.name: boolean?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a boolean form, or a block that implements '**boolean**'.

```
true boolean? leaves: true
[ true $: __boolean__ this ] open boolean? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a boolean form, or a block that implements '**boolean**'.

words.name: asBoolean
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a boolean form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asBoolean
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
true asBoolean leaves: true
false asBoolean leaves: false
```

`__boolean__` hook can make a block usable in place of a boolean, provided its definition leaves a boolean or a block that implements `__boolean__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __boolean__ this ] @: a
true a asBoolean "beware: leaves an instance of a"
true a a asBoolean "beware: leaves an instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a boolean form, dies if it's not.

words.name: builtin?
words.markdown: leaves whether Form is a builtin form.
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a builtin form.

words.name: asBuiltin
words.markdown:
asserts Form is a Builtin, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
'foo' asBuiltin
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
#+ here asBuiltin toQuote leaves: '[ native code ]'
```
words.primer: asserts Form is a Builtin, dies if it's not.

words.name: color?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a color form, or a block that implements '**color**'.

```
0 0 0 rgb color? leaves: true
[ 0 0 0 rgb $: __color__ this ] open color? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a color form, or a block that implements '**color**'.

words.name: asColor
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Color form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asColor
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
0 0 0 rgb asColor toQuote leaves: 'rgb(0, 0, 0)'
```

`__color__` hook can make a block usable in place of a color, provided its definition leaves a color or a block that implements `__color__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __color__ this ] @: a
0 0 0 rgb a asColor "beware: leaves an instance of a"
0 0 0 rgb a a asColor "beware: leaves an instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Color form, dies if it's not.

words.name: byteslice?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a byteslice form, or a block that implements '**byteslice**'.

```
'hello world' toByteslice byteslice? leaves: true
[ [ 'Hi!' toByteslice ] $: __byteslice__ this ] open byteslice? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a byteslice form, or a block that implements '**byteslice**'.

words.name: asByteslice
words.markdown:
asserts that Form is a Byteslice form, dies if it's not.

For example, the following expression dies:

```
100 asByteslice
```

Et cetera for all other forms, except:

```
'hello world' toByteslice asByteslice leaves: '[byteslice, consists of 11 mutable byte(s)]'
```

`__byteslice__` hook can make a block usable in place of a byteslice, provided its definition leaves a byteslice or a block that implements `__byteslice__`:

```
[ $: x x $: __byteslice__ this ] @: a
'foo' toByteslice a asByteslice "beware: leaves an instance of a"
'foo' toByteslice a a asByteslice "beware: leaves an instance of a"
```
words.primer: asserts that Form is a Byteslice form, dies if it's not.

words.name: pushes
words.markdown: creates a definition for Name in Block that pushes Form when resolved there.
words.primer: creates a definition for Name in Block that pushes Form when resolved there.

words.name: opens
words.markdown: creates a definition for Name in Block that opens Form when resolved there.
words.primer: creates a definition for Name in Block that opens Form when resolved there.

words.name: entry:submit
words.markdown:
replaces the value form of an existing definition for Name in Submittable store (usually a block) to Form. Does not change whether the definition opens or pushes.

```
[ 'John Doe' $: fullName
  [ fullName count ] @: fullNameLength
] obj $: person

person.fullName leaves: 'John Doe'
person.fullNameLength leaves: 8

"Let's try to change the name:"
person #fullName 'Alice Bobette' entry:submit
person.fullName leaves: 'Alice Bobette'
person.fullNameLength leaves: 13

"Now let's change the way we compute the length; let's count
 how many double-Ts there are in the full name."
person #fullNameLength [ person.fullName 'tt' occurrences count ] entry:submit

"... just one:"
person.fullNameLength leaves: 1

"... or maybe multiple:"
person #fullName 'Tette Mopettitte' entry:submit
person.fullName leaves: 'Tette Mopettitte'
person.fullNameLength leaves: 3
```
words.primer: replaces the value form of an existing definition for Name in Submittable store (usually a block) to Form.

words.name: entry:exists?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Readable store (usually a block) can fetch value for Name.

```
[ orphan $: table
  orphan extendWith: [
    [ ${ name age score }
      [ name $: name
        age  $: age ] obj toDict $: record
      table record score pushes
    ] @: set
    [ ${ name age } table (this toDict) entry:fetch ] @: get
    [ ${ name age } table (this toDict) entry:exists? ] @: has?
    [ table entry:names map: [ $: record
        [
          record.name (31 ' ' lpad) (31 '...' fit)
          record.age toQuote (15 ' ' lpad) (15 '...' fit)
          (table record entry:fetch) toQuote (16 ' ' lpad) (16 '...' fit)
        ] vals sepBy: ' |'
      ] sepBy: '
'
    ] @: __quote__
  ]
] @: newScoreboard

newScoreboard $: scoreboard

'John Doe' 42 '100 points' scoreboard.set
'Johnanna Doe' 28 '170 points' scoreboard.set
'Alice H.' 19 '250 points' scoreboard.set
'David A.' 67 '90 points' scoreboard.set

scoreboard echo

"""STDOUT:
                 John Doe |             42 |      100 points⏎
             Johnanna Doe |             28 |      170 points⏎
                 Alice H. |             19 |      250 points⏎
                 David A. |             67 |       90 points⏎
"""

'John Doe' 42 scoreboard.get leaves: '100 points'
'Alice H.' 19 scoreboard.get leaves: '250 points'

'David A.' 67 scoreboard.has? leaves: true
'David A.' 123 scoreboard.has? leaves: false
'Peter Peterson' 19 scoreboard.has? leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether Readable store (usually a block) can fetch value for Name.

words.name: entry:fetch
words.markdown:
leaves the value Form with the given Name in Readable store (usually a block). Does not open the value form. Dies if Store does not contain an entry for Name.

```
[ 100 $: x 200 $: y ] obj $: a

a #x entry:fetch leaves: 100
a #y entry:fetch leaves: 200
a #a entry:fetch leaves: a "via inheritance"
```
words.primer: leaves the value Form with the given Name in Readable store (usually a block).

words.name: entry:fetch?
words.markdown:
leaves value Form of the entry with the given Name in Readable store (usually a block), follows it with `true`. If there is no entry with the given name leaves `false` only. Does not open the value form.

```
[ 100 $: x ] obj toOrphan $: a

a #x entry:fetch? leaves: [ 100 true ]
a #y entry:fetch? leaves: false

a ('Enter name> ' readLine or: okbye toWord) entry:fetch? br:
  [ 'Here is its value: ' _ ~ ]
  'Entry does not exist :('
echo
```
words.primer: leaves value Form of the entry with the given Name in Readable store (usually a block), follows it with `true`.

words.name: entry:open
words.markdown: resolves Name in Readable store and *opens* it if it is an opener, assuming Caller to be the opener block.
words.primer: resolves Name in Readable store and *opens* it if it is an opener, assuming Caller to be the opener block.

words.name: entry:flatFetch?
words.markdown:
leaves the value Form of the entry with the given Name in Block's dictionary. Follows it by `true` if it exists. Leaves only `false` if there is no such entry in Block. Block hierarchy (friends, parents) is not traversed. This word only looks at Block's own dictionary). Does not open the value Form.

```
[ 100 $: x 200 $: y ] obj $: myParent
[ 'hello' $: x ] obj $: myChild

(myParent -- myChild) drop

myParent #x entry:flatFetch? leaves: [ 100 true ]
myParent #y entry:flatFetch? leaves: [ 200 true ]
myChild #foobar entry:flatFetch? leaves: false

myChild #x entry:flatFetch? leaves: [ 'hello' true ]
myChild #foobar entry:flatFetch? leaves: false

"Even though myChild is a child of myParent and has access to 'y',
 `entry:flatFetch?` doesn't care."
myChild #y entry:flatFetch? leaves: false "doesn't inherit!"

"Compare it with `entry:fetch?`:"
myChild #y entry:fetch? leaves: [ 200 true ]
```
words.primer: leaves the value Form of the entry with the given Name in Block's dictionary.

words.name: entry:opener?
words.markdown:
leaves whether an entry with the given Name is an opener entry in Readable store (usually a block). Dies if Readable store has no entry with the given Name.

```
[ 100 $: x ] obj toOrphan $: foo

foo #x entry:opener? leaves: false
foo.x leaves: 100

"Change not only the value form for 'x' but also its type: make
 it an opener."
foo extend: [ [ 1 2 + ] @: x ]

foo #x entry:opener? leaves: true
foo.x leaves: 3
```
words.primer: leaves whether an entry with the given Name is an opener entry in Readable store (usually a block).

words.name: entry:delete
words.markdown:
removes the entry corresponding to Name form from the dictionary of Block if it exists there. Otherwise, does nothing.

```
100 $: x

[ 200 $: x ] obj $: foo

"'x' of foo shadows 'x' of toplevel block"
foo.x leaves: 200

"Let's try to remove it so it doesn't:"
foo #x entry:delete
foo.x leaves: 100
```
words.primer: removes the entry corresponding to Name form from the dictionary of Block if it exists there.

words.name: entry:wipeout
words.markdown:
removes all *owned* dictionary entries in Block.

```
[ 100 $: x
  200 $: y
] obj $: numbers

numbers entry:names leaves: [ [x y] ]

numbers entry:wipeout
numbers entry:names leaves: [ [] ]
```
words.primer: removes all *owned* dictionary entries in Block.

words.name: entry:pathTo?
words.effect: ( B N -- P F true / false ):
words.markdown:
leaves Path, a block describing the path to Form (including Block itself) under the corresponding Name (like `entry:fetch?`). Follows Path and Form with `true` indicating success, otherwise *only* `false` indicating that there is no Form corresponding to Name in Block or any of the blocks reachable from Block.

This word exists mainly for testing word lookup sanity. Feel free to use it if you find any reason to!

```
[ 100 $: x  'a' $: __quote__ ] obj $: a
[ 200 $: y  'b' $: __quote__ ] obj $: b
[ 300 $: z  'c' $: __quote__ ] obj $: c

a -- b -- c drop

[ a #x entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ a ] 100 true'
[ b #x entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ b a ] 100 true'
[ c #x entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ c b a ] 100 true'

[ b #y entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ b ] 200 true'
[ c #y entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ c b ] 200 true'

[ c #z entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: '[ c ] 300 true'

[ c #foo entry:pathTo? ] vals sepBy: ' ' leaves: 'false'
```
words.primer: leaves Path, a block describing the path to Form (including Block itself) under the corresponding Name (like `entry:fetch?`).

words.name: entry:names
words.markdown:
gathers all *owned* dictionary entry names of Block into Name block.

```
[ 100 200 ${ x y } ] obj $: myParent
[ 300 $: z ] obj $: myChild
[ 'Hello World' $: greeting ] obj $: myFriend

myParent -- myChild drop
myParent ·> myFriend drop
myChild ·> myFriend drop "for good measure :)"

myParent entry:names leaves: [ [y x] ]
myChild entry:names leaves: [ [z] ]
myFriend entry:names leaves: [ [greeting] ]
```
words.primer: gathers all *owned* dictionary entry names of Block into Name block.

words.name: entry:names*
words.markdown:
gathers all dictionary entry names *reachable* from Block to Name block. That is, gathers all entry names in Block, Block's parents, Block's friends, and so on. Explores the entire relative graph of Block.

Order is not guaranteed, and mainly depends on the appearance of Block's relative graph.

```
[ 100 200 ${ x y } ] obj toOrphan $: myParent
[ 300 $: z ] obj toOrphan $: myChild
[ 'Hello World' $: greeting ] obj toOrphan $: myFriend

myParent -- myChild drop
myParent ·> myFriend drop
myChild ·> myFriend drop

myParent entry:names* leaves: [ [y x greeting] ]
myChild entry:names* leaves: [ [z y x greeting] ]
myFriend entry:names* leaves: [ [greeting] ]
```
words.primer: gathers all dictionary entry names *reachable* from Block to Name block.

words.name: entry:values
words.markdown:
gathers all *owned* dictionary entry value forms of Block into Value block.

```
[ 100 200 ${ x y } ] obj $: myParent
[ 300 $: z ] obj $: myChild
[ 'Hello World' $: greeting ] obj $: myFriend

myParent -- myChild drop
myParent ·> myFriend drop
myChild ·> myFriend drop

myParent entry:values leaves: [ [200 100] ]
myChild entry:values leaves: [ [300] ]
myFriend entry:values leaves: [ ['Hello World'] ]
```
words.primer: gathers all *owned* dictionary entry value forms of Block into Value block.

words.name: entry:values*
words.markdown:
gathers all dictionary entry values *reachable* from Block to Name block. That is, gathers all entry values in Block, Block's parents, Block's friends, and so on. Explores the entire relative graph of Block.

Order is not guaranteed, and mainly depends on the appearance of Block's relative graph. Values may repeat if some blocks in this graph define entries with the same name.

```
[ 100 200 ${ x y } ] obj toOrphan $: myParent
[ 300 $: z ] obj toOrphan $: myChild
[ 'Hello World' $: greeting ] obj toOrphan $: myFriend

myParent -- myChild drop
myParent ·> myFriend drop
myChild ·> myFriend drop

myParent entry:values* leaves: [ [200 100 'Hello World'] ]
myChild entry:values* leaves: [ [300 200 100 'Hello World'] ]
myFriend entry:values* leaves: [ ['Hello World'] ]
```
words.primer: gathers all dictionary entry values *reachable* from Block to Name block.

words.name: entry:count
words.markdown:
leaves Entry count, that is, the amount of entries owned by (defined in) Block.

```
[ 100 200 ${ x y } ] obj $: myBlock

myBlock entry:count leaves: 2 "'x' and 'y'"
```
words.primer: leaves Entry count, that is, the amount of entries owned by (defined in) Block.

words.name: shallowCopy
words.markdown:
makes a shallow copy (sub-blocks are not copied) of Block's tape and dictionary, and leaves a Copy block with the tape copy, dictionary copy set as its tape, dictionary.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] $: a
a shallowCopy $: b
a #x 0 pushes
b #y 1 pushes
b 1 shove
a b 2echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 1 · ${y :: 1} ]⏎"
```
words.primer: makes a shallow copy (sub-blocks are not copied) of Block's tape and dictionary, and leaves a Copy block with the tape copy, dictionary copy set as its tape, dictionary.

words.name: resub
words.markdown:
replaces the substrate of Block with Other's substrate. This is useful if you want to swap Block's contents with Other's without changing Block's identity:

```
[ 1 2 3 ] $: a
[ 'a' 'b' 'c' ] $: b
b #x 0 pushes
b echo
"STDOUT: [ 'a' 'b' 'c' · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"

a b resub
b echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"
```

Note that since *substrate* is replaced, not *tape*, the cursor position is saved:

```
a b 2echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 ]⏎"
"STDOUT: [ 'a' 'b' 'c' · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"

b 2 |-
a b 2echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 ]⏎"
"STDOUT: [ 'a' | 'b' 'c' · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"

a b resub
b echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 | 2 3 · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"
```
words.primer: replaces the substrate of Block with Other's substrate.

words.name: fromLeft
words.markdown:
leaves Index-th Element from left in Block, Quote, or Byteslice form.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] 0 fromLeft leaves: 1
```
words.primer: leaves Index-th Element from left in Block, Quote, or Byteslice form.

words.name: fromRight
words.markdown:
leaves Index-th Element from right in Block, Quote, or Byteslice form.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] 0 fromRight leaves: 3
[ 1 2 3 ] 1 fromRight leaves: 2
[ 1 2 3 ] 2 fromRight leaves: 1
```
words.primer: leaves Index-th Element from right in Block, Quote, or Byteslice form.

words.name: fromLeft*
words.markdown:
leaves Elements block (if given a Block), Result quote (if given a Quote), or Result byteslice form (if given a Byteslice form) with N forms/ chars/bytes from left in Block/Quote/Byteslice form. If N is larger than Block/Quote/Byteslice form count, it is made equal to Block/Quote/Byteslice form count. Dies if N is negative.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] 1 fromLeft* leaves: [ [ 1 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 2 fromLeft* leaves: [ [ 1 2 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 3 fromLeft* leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 100 fromLeft* leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]
'hello' 3 fromLeft* leaves: 'hel'
```
words.primer: leaves Elements block (if given a Block), Result quote (if given a Quote), or Result byteslice form (if given a Byteslice form) with N forms/ chars/bytes from left in Block/Quote/Byteslice form.

words.name: fromRight*
words.markdown:
leaves Elements block (if given a Block), Result quote (if given a Quote), or Result byteslice form (if given a Byteslice form) with N forms/ chars/bytes from right in Block/Quote/Byteslice form. If N is larger than Block/Quote/Byteslice form count, it is made equal to Block/Quote/Byteslice form count. Dies if N is negative.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] 1 fromRight* leaves: [ [ 3 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 2 fromRight* leaves: [ [ 2 3 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 3 fromRight* leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]
[ 1 2 3 ] 100 fromRight* leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: leaves Elements block (if given a Block), Result quote (if given a Quote), or Result byteslice form (if given a Byteslice form) with N forms/ chars/bytes from right in Block/Quote/Byteslice form.

words.markdown: leaves the Sum of two decimals.
words.primer: leaves the Sum of two decimals.

words.markdown: leaves the Difference of two decimals.
words.primer: leaves the Difference of two decimals.

words.markdown: leaves the Product of two decimals.
words.primer: leaves the Product of two decimals.

words.markdown: leaves the Quotient of two decimals.
words.primer: leaves the Quotient of two decimals.

words.name: mod
words.markdown: leaves the Modulo of two decimals.
words.primer: leaves the Modulo of two decimals.

words.markdown: raises A to the power B, leaves Result.
words.primer: raises A to the power B, leaves Result.

words.name: round
words.markdown:
rounds Decimal towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal. If both neighboring integers are equidistant, rounds towards the even neighbor (Banker's rounding).

```
1 round leaves: 1
1.23 round leaves: 1

1.5 round leaves: 2
1.67 round leaves: 2

2.5 round leaves: 2 "rounds towards the even neighbor"
```
words.primer: rounds Decimal towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal.

words.name: floor
words.markdown:
rounds Decimal *down* towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal.

```
1 floor leaves: 1
1.23 floor leaves: 1

1.5 floor leaves: 1
1.67 floor leaves: 1

2.5 floor leaves: 2

-2.5 floor leaves: -3 "rounds down!"
```
words.primer: rounds Decimal *down* towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal.

words.name: ceil
words.markdown:
rounds Decimal *up* towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal.

```
1 ceil leaves: 1
1.23 ceil leaves: 2

1.5 ceil leaves: 2
1.67 ceil leaves: 2

2.5 ceil leaves: 3

-2.5 ceil leaves: -2 "rounds up!"
```
words.primer: rounds Decimal *up* towards the nearest integer, leaves the corresoinding Rounded decimal.

words.name: trunc
words.markdown:
rounds Decimal towards zero, leaves the resulting Rounded decimal.

```
1 trunc leaves: 1
1.23 trunc leaves: 1
1.5 trunc leaves: 1
1.67 trunc leaves: 1
2.5 trunc leaves: 2

-2.3 trunc leaves:  -2
```
words.primer: rounds Decimal towards zero, leaves the resulting Rounded decimal.

words.name: sqrt
words.markdown: leaves the square Root of Decimal.
words.primer: leaves the square Root of Decimal.

words.name: cos
words.markdown: leaves Decimal cosine of Angle in radians.
words.primer: leaves Decimal cosine of Angle in radians.

words.name: sin
words.markdown: leaves Decimal sine of Angle in radians.
words.primer: leaves Decimal sine of Angle in radians.

words.name: rand
words.markdown: leaves a Random decimal between 0 and 1.
words.primer: leaves a Random decimal between 0 and 1.

words.name: sliceQuoteAt
words.markdown:
for the given Quote, leaves the Part before and Part after Slice point.

```
'hello world' 2 sliceQuoteAt leaves: [ 'he' 'llo world' ]
```
words.primer: for the given Quote, leaves the Part before and Part after Slice point.

words.name: count
words.markdown: leaves N, the amount of elements/graphemes/ bytes in Block/Quote/Byteslice form.
words.primer: leaves N, the amount of elements/graphemes/ bytes in Block/Quote/Byteslice form.

words.name: chr
words.markdown: leaves a quote that consists of a single character with the given Unicode codepoint.
words.primer: leaves a quote that consists of a single character with the given Unicode codepoint.

words.name: ord
words.markdown: leaves the Unicode codepoint for the first character in Quote. Dies if Quote is empty.
words.primer: leaves the Unicode codepoint for the first character in Quote.

words.name: lpad
words.markdown:
appends consecutive characters from Padding quote (the last one is repeated if no more follow) to the left of Quote, until Quote count becomes equal to Total length. Leaves the resulting Justified quote. If Quote count is greater than or equal to Total length, Quote is left unchanged as the Justified quote.

```
'hello' 10 '-' lpad leaves: '-----hello'
'hello' 10 ':-' lpad leaves: ':----hello'
'hello' 7 'XYZABC' lpad leaves: 'XYhello'
'hello' 9 'XYZABC' lpad leaves: 'XYZAhello'
```
words.primer: appends consecutive characters from Padding quote (the last one is repeated if no more follow) to the left of Quote, until Quote count becomes equal to Total length.

words.name: rpad
words.markdown:
appends consecutive characters from Padding quote (the last one is repeated if no more follow) to the right of Quote, until Quote count becomes equal to Total length. Leaves the resulting Justified quote. If Quote count is greater than or equal to Total length, Quote is left unchanged as the Justified quote.

```
'hello' 10 '-' rpad leaves: 'hello-----'
'hello' 10 ' -' rpad leaves: 'hello ----'
'hello' 7 'foobar' rpad leaves: 'hellofo'
```
words.primer: appends consecutive characters from Padding quote (the last one is repeated if no more follow) to the right of Quote, until Quote count becomes equal to Total length.

words.name: fit
words.markdown:
if Quote is longer than Total length, truncates it so that it can fit Ellipsis quote, and stitches the truncated Quote with the Ellipsis quote, forming Fit quote which is then left on the stack.

Essentially, Fit quote is guaranteed to be of Total length characters **or less!**.

```
'hello' 10 '…' fit leaves: 'hello'
'hello world' 10 '…' fit leaves: 'hello wor…'
'hello world' 8 '' fit leaves: 'hello wo'
'Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet' 10 '-' fit leaves: 'Lorem ipsu-'
'Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet' 24 '… (hidden)' fit leaves: 'Lorem ipsum do… (hidden)'
```
words.primer: if Quote is longer than Total length, truncates it so that it can fit Ellipsis quote, and stitches the truncated Quote with the Ellipsis quote, forming Fit quote which is then left on the stack.

words.name: |at
words.markdown: leaves N, the position of the cursor in Block.
words.primer: leaves N, the position of the cursor in Block.

words.name: |to
words.markdown: moves the cursor in Block to N.
words.primer: moves the cursor in Block to N.

words.markdown: moves stack cursor once to the left.
words.primer: moves stack cursor once to the left.

words.markdown: moves stack cursor once to the left.
words.primer: moves stack cursor once to the left.

words.name: |slice
words.markdown: slices Block at cursor. Leaves Left half and Right half.
words.primer: slices Block at cursor.

words.name: cherry
words.markdown: drops Block and Element before cursor in Block (and moves cursor back once), leaves Element.
words.primer: drops Block and Element before cursor in Block (and moves cursor back once), leaves Element.

words.name: shove
words.markdown: adds Element before cursor in Block (and moves cursor forward once), drops both.
words.primer: adds Element before cursor in Block (and moves cursor forward once), drops both.

words.name: shove*
words.markdown:
adds elements before cursor in Element block after the cursor in Block.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] $: xs
xs [ 4 5 6 ] shove*
xs leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 4 5 6 "|" ] ]

[ 1 | 2 3 ] $: ys
ys [ 100 200 300 ] shove*
ys leaves: [ 1 100 200 300 | 2 3 ]
```
words.primer: adds elements before cursor in Element block after the cursor in Block.

words.name: eject
words.markdown: drops and leaves the Form after cursor in Block.
words.primer: drops and leaves the Form after cursor in Block.

words.name: inject
words.markdown: inserts Form to Block: adds Form to Block, and moves cursor back again.
words.primer: inserts Form to Block: adds Form to Block, and moves cursor back again.

words.name: thru
words.markdown:
moves cursor after Form, and leaves Form. Dies if cursor is at the end.

Note: prefer `thru` to `eject` because `eject` modifies the block, and that may cause a tape copy which uses up a bit of memory and resources. The difference would matter only in high load scenarios, though.

Note: anything that *does not* `ahead inject` will be OK with `ahead thru`. And even if it does `ahead inject`, still, there are ways to overcome the problems from not `ahead eject`ing.
words.primer: moves cursor after Form, and leaves Form.

words.name: thruBlock
words.markdown: similar to `thru` for Block. If form after cursor is a Block form, it is left. If it is a Value form, then it is enclosed in a new block whose parent is Block.
words.primer: similar to `thru` for Block.

words.name: top
words.markdown: leaves the top Form in Block.
words.primer: leaves the top Form in Block.

words.name: mergeDicts
words.markdown:
copies entries from Donor block's dictionary to Recipient block's dictionary. Donor entries override same-named entries in Recipient. Donor entries starting with one or more underscores are not imported.

```
[ ] $: a
a #x 100 pushes
a #_private 'Fool!' pushes
[ ] $: b
b #y 200 pushes

a b 2echo
"STDOUT: [ · ${x :: 100} ${_private :: 'Fool!'} ]⏎"
"STDOUT: [ · ${y :: 200} ]⏎"

b a mergeDicts
b echo
"STDOUT: [ · ${y :: 200} ${x :: 100} ]⏎"
```
words.primer: copies entries from Donor block's dictionary to Recipient block's dictionary.

words.name: sortUsing!
words.markdown:
leaves Block sorted inplace. Forms in Block are compared using Comparator block.

Comparator block is opened with two forms on the stack; let's call them A and B. If Comparator block leaves a negative decimal (conventionally `-1`), then `A < B`. If Comparator block leaves `0`, then `A = B`. If Comparator block leaves a positive decimal (conventionally `1`), then `A > B`.

Dies if Comparator block leaves any other (kind of) form.

Ignores all forms but the topmost for Comparator block.

```
[ 3 2 1 ] [ - ] sortUsing! leaves: [ 1 2 3 ]
```
words.primer: leaves Block sorted inplace.

words.name: getErrorDetails
words.markdown: leaves Details quote containing error details of an Error object.
words.primer: leaves Details quote containing error details of an Error object.

words.name: toQuote
words.markdown: leaves Quote representation of Form.
words.primer: leaves Quote representation of Form.

words.name: toByteslice
words.markdown: leaves immutable Byteslice for Quote.
words.primer: leaves immutable Byteslice for Quote.

words.name: replaceAll
words.markdown:
replaces all instances of Pattern quote in Source quote with Quote. Leaves the Resulting quote.

```
'hello' 'l' 'y' replaceAll leaves: 'heyyo'
```
words.primer: replaces all instances of Pattern quote in Source quote with Quote.

words.name: effect
words.markdown:
leaves Effect quote for Form.

If Form is not a block nor a builtin, it is simply converted to quote in the same way as `toQuote`.

If Form is a block or a builtin, an attempt is made at extracting a stack effect expression from its comment. If the attempt fails, Form's description is left. If the attempt was successful, the extracted stack effect quote is added onto the stack as Effect quote.

```
100 effect leaves: '100'
true effect leaves: 'true'

[] effect leaves: 'a block'
[ "Hello World" ] effect leaves: 'a block'
[ "( -- ) "] effect leaves: '( -- )'

#+ here effect leaves: '( A B -- S )' "(yours may differ)"
#map: here effect leaves: '( Lb B -- MLb )'
```
words.primer: leaves Effect quote for Form.

words.name: die
words.markdown: dies with Details quote/Error object.
words.primer: dies with Details quote/Error object.

words.name: stitch
words.markdown: quote concatenation.
words.primer: quote concatenation.

words.name: reparent
words.markdown: changes the parent of Child block to Parent block. Lookup cycles are allowed and handled gracefully.
words.primer: changes the parent of Child block to Parent block.

words.name: befriend
words.markdown:
adds Friend to Block's friend list.

Friends are asked for word entries after parents, grandparents etc. have failed to retrieve them. This recurses, e.g. friends ask their own friends and so on, until the entry is found. Lookup cycles are allowed and handled gracefully.

```
[ 100 $: x this ] open $: a
[ 200 $: y this ] open $: b
a b befriend
b a befriend
a.x echo
"STDOUT: 100⏎"

a.y echo
"STDOUT: 200⏎"

b.x echo
"STDOUT: 100⏎"

b.y echo
"STDOUT: 200⏎"

a #x [ 'I've changed!' echo ] opens

a.x
"STDOUT: I've changed!⏎"
b.x
"STDOUT: I've changed!⏎"
```
words.primer: adds Friend to Block's friend list.

words.name: unfriend
words.markdown:
removes Friend from Block's friend list. Does nothing if Friend is not in the friend list. See `befriend`.

```
[ 100 $: x this ] open $: a
[ 200 $: y this ] open $: b
a b befriend
a.x echo
"STDOUT: 100⏎"
a.y echo
"STDOUT: 200⏎"
a b unfriend
a.x echo
"STDOUT: 100⏎"
a.y echo
"Sorry: no value form found for 'y'."
```
words.primer: removes Friend from Block's friend list.

words.name: friends
words.markdown:
leaves Friend list of Block. See `befriend`.

```
[ 100 $: x this ] open $: a
[ 200 $: y this ] open $: b
a b befriend
a friends count echo
"STDOUT: 1⏎"
a friends first b same? echo
"STDOUT: true⏎"
a.y echo
"STDOUT: 200⏎"
a friends [ drop ] hydrate
a friends count echo
"STDOUT: 0⏎"
a.y echo
"Sorry: no value form found for 'y'."
```
words.primer: leaves Friend list of Block.

words.name: slurp
words.markdown: parses Quote and adds all forms from Quote to Block.
words.primer: parses Quote and adds all forms from Quote to Block.

words.name: orphan
words.markdown:
creates and leaves a new orphan Block.

Orphan blocks are blocks without a parent. Therefore, they do not participate in any block hierarchy until they acquire some friends, or a parent, and when (and whether) this should happen if for you — not Novika, as is usually the case — to decide.

```
'Outer A' $: a
'Outer B' $: b

orphan $: x

[ [ drop 'I die!' ] @: __died__ x.a ] do leaves: 'I die!'
[ [ drop 'I die too!' ] @: __died__ x.b ] do leaves: 'I die too!'

"Define `a` and `b` on the block itself. As you can see there
 is no inheritance."
x extend: [
  100 $: a
  200 $: b
]

"Now `a` and `b` are looked up fine."
x.a leaves: 100
x.b leaves: 200
```
words.primer: creates and leaves a new orphan Block.

words.name: orphan?
words.markdown:
leaves whether the given Block is an orphan (see `orphan`).

```
orphan orphan? leaves: true
[ "I'm not an orphan" ] orphan? leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves whether the given Block is an orphan (see `orphan`).

words.name: toOrphan
words.markdown:
makes Block an orphan (destroys the link with its parent).

```
0 $: x
[ ] $: b
b . x echo
"STDOUT: 0⏎"

b toOrphan leaves: [ [ ] ]
. x
"Sorry: no value form found for 'x'""
```
words.primer: makes Block an orphan (destroys the link with its parent).

words.name: toTape
words.markdown:
leaves Tape block for Block, i.e., the tape part of Block. Useful for e.g. comparing two blocks only for tape content, when Block may have dictionary entries.

Lookup hierarchy is destroyed: Tape block is an orphan.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] $: a
a #x 0 pushes
a (a toTape) 2echo
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 · ${x :: 0} ]⏎"
"STDOUT: [ 1 2 3 ]⏎"
```
words.primer: leaves Tape block for Block, i.e., the tape part of Block.

words.name: toDict
words.markdown:
leaves Dictionary block for Block, i.e., the dictionary part of Block. Useful for e.g. comparing two blocks only for dictionary content in case tape contents differ.

Lookup hierarchy is destroyed: Dictionary block is an orphan.

```
[ ${ x y } this ] @: createPoint

10 20 createPoint $: a
10 20 createPoint $: b

a b = leaves: false

"And not for the reason you might think of. Their TAPES are not
 equal; `a` and `b` are not only objects, they are also pieces
 of code that led to each one's creation (sort of)."
a toQuote leaves: '[ ${ x y } this · ${x :: 10} ${y :: 20} ]'
b toQuote leaves: '[ ${ x y } this · ${x :: 10} ${y :: 20} ]'

"Let's strip the code using toDict:"
a toDict leaves: '[ · ${x :: 10} ${y :: 20} ]'
b toDict leaves: '[ · ${x :: 10} ${y :: 20} ]'
       = leaves: true "< now they're equal"
```
words.primer: leaves Dictionary block for Block, i.e., the dictionary part of Block.

words.name: desc
words.markdown:
leaves the Description quote of the given Form.

```
100 desc leaves: 'decimal number 100'
'foobar' desc leaves: 'quote 'foobar''
[ 1 2 3 ] desc leaves: 'a block'
[ "I am a block" 1 2 3 ] desc leaves: 'I am a block'
true desc leaves: 'boolean true'
```
words.primer: leaves the Description quote of the given Form.

words.name: typedesc
words.markdown:
leaves the type Description quote of the given Form.

```
100 typedesc leaves: 'decimal'
'foobar' typedesc leaves: 'quote'
[ 1 2 3 ] typedesc leaves: 'block'
[ "I am a block" 1 2 3 ] typedesc leaves: 'block'
true typedesc leaves: 'boolean'
```
words.primer: leaves the type Description quote of the given Form.

words.name: nki:toBlock
words.markdown:
leaves Block for the given Byteslice form, assumed to contain a well-formed Novika image created with `nki:captureAll`, `nki:captureNeighborhood`, or otherwise. Dies if Byteslice form is an invalid Novika image, or isn't a Novika image.

For code example, see `nki:captureNeighborhood`.
words.primer: leaves Block for the given Byteslice form, assumed to contain a well-formed Novika image created with `nki:captureAll`, `nki:captureNeighborhood`, or otherwise.

words.name: nki:captureAll
words.markdown:
thoroughly, recursively captures entire hierarchy of Block (its parents, prototype, friends, tape, and dictionary), and leaves the resulting Novika image as a Byteslice form.

Archives image payload using Gzip, fast.

If you're a visual type of person, imagine this word and all related facilities as a kind of "mold", which carefully, in an ordered fashion "fills up" a maze, until all paths were explored and all exits found.

For code example, see `nki:captureNeighborhood`.
words.primer: thoroughly, recursively captures entire hierarchy of Block (its parents, prototype, friends, tape, and dictionary), and leaves the resulting Novika image as a Byteslice form.

words.name: nki:captureNeighborhood
words.markdown:
like `nki:captureAll`, but rather than capturing all reachable blocks, captures only Block's neighborhood. Leaves the resulting Byteslice form.

Archives image payload using Gzip, fast.

We store each block in Block's tape and dictionary in a list, then ask that block to do the same. When recursion finishes, the resulting list is called *block neighborhood*.

Parent, friends, and prototype of the given block are reconstructed *if and only if they are in the block neighborhood*.

```
[ 1 2 3 ] nki:captureNeighborhood $: imgN

imgN toQuote leaves: '[byteslice, consists of 111 byte(s)]' "yours may differ!"
imgN nki:toBlock leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]

"As opposed to nki:captureAll, which will capture EVERYTHING
 it can reach:"
[ 1 2 3 ] nki:captureAll $: imgA

imgA toQuote leaves: '[byteslice, consists of 38298 byte(s)]' "yours may differ!"

"Note: [ 1 2 3 ] lives in a parallel universe now, with
 its own friends, prototypes, toplevel block, and so on!
 It doesn't have any links whatsoever to the whoever-it-was
 that called nki:captureAll!"
imgA nki:toBlock leaves: [ [ 1 2 3 ] ]
```
words.primer: like `nki:captureAll`, but rather than capturing all reachable blocks, captures only Block's neighborhood.

words.name: nki:captureAllRaw
words.markdown: same as `nki:captureAll`, but does not archive image payload obtained from capturing Block. May yield very large Byteslice forms.
words.primer: same as `nki:captureAll`, but does not archive image payload obtained from capturing Block.

words.name: nki:captureNeighborhoodRaw
words.markdown: same as `nki:captureNeighborhood`, but does not archive image payload obtained from capturing Block. May yield large Byteslice forms.
words.primer: same as `nki:captureNeighborhood`, but does not archive image payload obtained from capturing Block.

words.name: nki:captureAllGzipBest
words.markdown: same as `nki:captureAll`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Gzip, best.
words.primer: same as `nki:captureAll`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Gzip, best.

words.name: nki:captureNeighborhoodGzipBest
words.markdown: same as `nki:captureNeighborhood`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Gzip, best.

words.markdown: same as `nki:captureAll`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Brotli, fast.

words.markdown: same as `nki:captureNeighborhood`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Brotli, fast.

words.name: nki:captureAllBrotliBest
words.markdown: same as `nki:captureAll`, but archives image payload obtained from capturing Block using Brotli, best.

words.name: console:on
words.markdown: enables the console. Must be called before using any other console-related word.
words.primer: enables the console.

words.name: console:off
words.markdown: disables the console. Must be called at the end of your program or when you don't need console anymore.
words.primer: disables the console.

words.name: console:compat
words.markdown: enables the compatibility color output mode. In this mode, only 8 colors are available. All RGB colors are automatically reduced to one of those 8 colors.
words.primer: enables the compatibility color output mode.

words.name: console:256
words.markdown: enables the 256-color output mode. In this mode, 256 colors are available. All RGB colors are automatically reduced to one of those 256 colors.
words.primer: enables the 256-color output mode.

words.name: console:truecolor
words.markdown: enables the truecolor output mode. In this mode, all colors are available and are passed to the console as-is.
words.primer: enables the truecolor output mode.

words.name: console:size
words.markdown: leaves the Console width (in columns) and Console height (in rows).
words.primer: leaves the Console width (in columns) and Console height (in rows).

words.name: console:setTimeout
words.markdown:
sets input timeout to Duration, given in *milliseconds*.

* If Duration is negative, `console:readKey` will wait for input indefinitely (i.e., until there is input).

* If Duration is zero, `console:readKey` won't wait for input at all, but make note if there is any at the moment.

* If Duration is positive, `console:readKey` will peek during the timeout window.
words.primer: sets input timeout to Duration, given in *milliseconds*.

words.name: console:readKey
words.markdown: peeks or waits for input. See `console:setTimeout`. Refreshes the input state. Use `console:hadKeyPressed` and friends to explore the input state afterwards.
words.primer: peeks or waits for input.

words.name: console:hadKeyPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether any key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether any key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadCtrlPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the CTRL key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the CTRL key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadAltPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the ALT key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the ALT key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadShiftPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the SHIFT key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the SHIFT key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadBackspacePressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the Backspace key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the Backspace key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadFnPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether one of the function keys F1-F12 was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether one of the function keys F1-F12 was pressed.

words.name: console:hadInsertPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the INSERT key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the INSERT key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadDeletePressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the DELETE key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the DELETE key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadHomePressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the HOME key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the HOME key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadEndPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the END key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the END key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadPageUpPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the PAGE UP key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the PAGE UP key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadPageDownPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the PAGE DOWN key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the PAGE DOWN key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadLeftPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the LEFT ARROW key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the LEFT ARROW key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadRightPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the RIGHT ARROW key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the RIGHT ARROW key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadUpPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the UP ARROW key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the UP ARROW key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadDownPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether the DOWN ARROW key was pressed.
words.primer: leaves whether the DOWN ARROW key was pressed.

words.name: console:hadCharPressed?
words.markdown: leaves whether EXCLUSIVELY a printable character key was pressed (no CTRL, ALT, etc.) Whether the SHIFT key was pressed or not is ignored.
words.primer: leaves whether EXCLUSIVELY a printable character key was pressed (no CTRL, ALT, etc.)

words.name: console:getCharPressed
words.markdown:
leaves Char quote for the key that was pressed. Usually a lowercase or uppercase letter; but also may look like `' '` or `'	'`, etc.)

In case the key that was pressed cannot be represented by the means of a quote, or if the user did not press any key, an empty quote is left in place of Char quote.
words.primer: leaves Char quote for the key that was pressed.

words.name: console:change
words.markdown: changes the color of the cell at X, Y coordinates to be the foreground, background colors set by ink's `withEchoFg` and `withEchoBg`.
words.primer: changes the color of the cell at X, Y coordinates to be the foreground, background colors set by ink's `withEchoFg` and `withEchoBg`.

words.name: console:appendEcho
words.markdown: appends echo of Form at an X and Y position (in columns and rows correspondingly) using the foreground, background colors set by ink's `withEchoFg` and `withEchoBg`.
words.primer: appends echo of Form at an X and Y position (in columns and rows correspondingly) using the foreground, background colors set by ink's `withEchoFg` and `withEchoBg`.

words.name: console:withReverseAppendEcho
words.markdown: appends Form with foreground and background colors swapped with each other (background color is set to foreground color, and vice versa).
words.primer: appends Form with foreground and background colors swapped with each other (background color is set to foreground color, and vice versa).

words.name: console:present
words.markdown: syncs internal buffer and console.
words.primer: syncs internal buffer and console.

words.name: console:clear
words.markdown: clears console with primary colors.
words.primer: clears console with primary colors.

words.name: disk:has?
words.markdown: leaves whether Path quote exists on the disk.
words.primer: leaves whether Path quote exists on the disk.

words.name: disk:canRead?
words.markdown: leaves whether Path quote exists and is readable.
words.primer: leaves whether Path quote exists and is readable.

words.name: disk:hasDir?
words.markdown: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a directory.
words.primer: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a directory.

words.name: disk:hasFile?
words.markdown: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a file.
words.primer: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a file.

words.name: disk:hasSymlink?
words.markdown: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a symlink.
words.primer: leaves whether Path quote exists and points to a symlink.

words.name: disk:dirEmpty?
words.markdown: leaves whether the directory at Path quote is empty. Dies if Path quote points to something other than a directory, or doesn't exist.
words.primer: leaves whether the directory at Path quote is empty.

words.name: disk:join
words.markdown:
leaves Path quote, which is the result of joining Base path quote and Child path quote using the platform-specific path separator.

```
'hello' 'world' disk:join leaves: 'hello/world' "On Unix"
'hello' 'world' disk:join leaves: 'hello\world' "On Windows"
```
words.primer: leaves Path quote, which is the result of joining Base path quote and Child path quote using the platform-specific path separator.

words.name: disk:pwd
words.markdown: leaves Path quote pointing to the current working directory.
words.primer: leaves Path quote pointing to the current working directory.

words.name: disk:home
words.markdown: leaves Path quote pointing to the user's home directory.
words.primer: leaves Path quote pointing to the user's home directory.

words.name: disk:touch
words.markdown:
creates an empty file at the location that Path quote points to. Does nothing if Path already exists.

```
disk:pwd 'demo.txt' disk:join $: demoPath
demoPath disk:touch 'Hey!' demoPath disk:write
demoPath disk:read leaves: 'Hey!'
```
words.primer: creates an empty file at the location that Path quote points to.

words.name: disk:mkdir
words.markdown:
creates an empty directory at the location that Path quote points to. Also creates any non-existing intermediate directories. Does nothing if Path quote already points to an existing directory, file, symlink, etc.

```
disk:pwd 'demo-dir-a' disk:join
         'demo-dir-b' disk:join
         'demo-dir-c' disk:join $: demoDirPath

demoDirPath disk:mkdir
demoDirPath disk:hasDir? leaves: true
```
words.primer: creates an empty directory at the location that Path quote points to.

words.name: disk:copy
words.markdown:
copies whatever Source path quote points to, to the location that Destination path quote points to. If Source is a directory, it is copied recursively.

If copy process failed (for instance if there is already something at Destination path quote), dies.

```
disk:pwd 'a.txt' disk:join $: pathToA
disk:pwd 'b.txt' disk:join $: pathToB

pathToA disk:touch pathToA 'Content of file a.txt' disk:write
pathToA pathToB disk:copy

pathToA disk:read leaves: 'Content of file a.txt'
pathToB disk:read leaves: 'Content of file a.txt'
```
words.primer: copies whatever Source path quote points to, to the location that Destination path quote points to.

words.name: disk:read
words.markdown:
leaves Quote containing the content of the file that Path quote points to. Dies if Path quote points to nothing or if it points to something other than a file.

```
disk:pwd 'a.txt' disk:join $: pathToA
pathToA disk:touch 'Hello World' pathToA disk:write
pathToA disk:read leaves: 'Hello World'
```
words.primer: leaves Quote containing the content of the file that Path quote points to.

words.name: disk:write
words.markdown:
(over)writes the content of the file that Path quote points to, with the given Quote or Byteslice form. Dies if Path quote points to nothing or if it points to something other than a file.

```
disk:pwd 'a.txt' disk:join $: pathToA
pathToA disk:touch 'Hello World' pathToA disk:write
pathToA disk:read leaves: 'Hello World'

[ 0 $: count
  [ count dup 1 + =: count ]
] @: counter

counter @: inc
inc leaves: 0
inc leaves: 1
inc leaves: 2

disk:pwd 'counter.nki' disk:join $: pathToCounter
pathToCounter disk:touch

"Save inc state using NKI and write the resulting byteslice
 to the file we've just created. Note that captureAll is similar
 to deep copy (it copies the *entire* Novika environment including
 the standard library), it's not the best way to do this but
 by far the easiest."
(this -> inc nki:captureAll) pathToCounter disk:write

pathToCounter disk:read toByteslice nki:toBlock @: incFromDisk

incFromDisk leaves: 3
incFromDisk leaves: 4
incFromDisk leaves: 5
```
words.primer: (over)writes the content of the file that Path quote points to, with the given Quote or Byteslice form.

words.name: ffi:library?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a foreign library form.

```
'foo' ffi:getLibrary ffi:library? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a foreign library form.

words.name: ffi:layout?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a foreign layout form.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:layout? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a foreign layout form.

words.name: ffi:struct&?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a struct reference view form.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:allocateStruct& $: point&
point& ffi:struct&? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a struct reference view form.

words.name: ffi:struct~?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is an inline struct view form.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:allocateStruct~ $: point~
point~ ffi:struct~? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is an inline struct view form.

words.name: ffi:union?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a union view form.

```
[ chr char ord u8 ] ffi:createLayout $: quux

quux ffi:allocateUnion $: quuxU
quuxU ffi:union? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a union view form.

words.name: ffi:hole?
words.markdown:
leaves whether Form is a hole.

```
#i32 ffi:hole $: intHole

intHole ffi:hole? leaves: true
```
words.primer: leaves whether Form is a hole.

words.name: ffi:getLibrary?
words.markdown:
leaves Library form followed by true if dynamic library with the given Id exists and was loaded & retrieved successfully; otherwise, leaves false.

Opening Library form allows one to expose functions from the underlying dynamic library (.so on Linux, .dll on Windows, .dylib on Mac). See FFI documentation on GitHub Wiki for more details and examples.

```
'SDL2' ffi:getLibrary? leaves: [ "[foreign library]" true ]
'random-nonexisting-library' ffi:getLibrary? leaves: false
```
words.primer: leaves Library form followed by true if dynamic library with the given Id exists and was loaded & retrieved successfully; otherwise, leaves false.

words.name: ffi:getLibrary
words.markdown:
leaves Library form if dynamic library with the given Id exists and was loaded & retrieved successfully; otherwise, dies.

Opening Library form allows one to expose functions from the underlying dynamic library (.so on Linux, .dll on Windows, .dylib on Mac). See FFI documentation on GitHub Wiki for more details and examples.

```
'SDL2' ffi:getLibrary ffi:library? leaves: true
'random-nonexisting-library' ffi:getLibrary "Dies: no such library"
```
words.primer: leaves Library form if dynamic library with the given Id exists and was loaded & retrieved successfully; otherwise, dies.

words.name: ffi:createLayout
words.markdown:
parses Layout block and leaves the resulting Struct layout form.

Struct layouts are a generalization over structs (heap- allocated and stack-allocated) and unions. They literally describe how structs (unions) are layed out in memory.

Layout block consists of *name words followed by type words*. See the example below. A reference to another struct layout can be made in Layout block using the prefixes `&` (heap- allocated struct, i.e., pointer to struct), `~` (inline or stack-allocated struct), and `?` (stack-allocated union).

Inline struct cycles are forbidden. Union cycles are forbidden. Either could be hidden behind a reference/pointer.

Layout block is parsed lazily (on first use, e.g., by `toQuote`, `allocateStruct` variants, `=`, etc.) Therefore, you can define self-referential structs, mutually referential structs, and reference layouts that are defined later.

See FFI documentation on GitHub Wiki for a list of available types and the corresponding C types.

```
[ x f32
  y f32
] ffi:createLayout $: point

[ datum ~point    "<- inline struct"
  next &pointNode "<- struct reference"
] ffi:createLayout $: pointNode

[ asPoint &point
  asPointNode ~pointNode
] ffi:createLayout $: pointNodeUnion

[ type u8
  value ?pointNodeUnion "<- stack-allocated union"
] ffi:createLayout $: pointNodeOrPoint
```
words.primer: parses Layout block and leaves the resulting Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:allocateStruct~
words.markdown:
allocates Inline struct view for the given Struct layout form. If the struct is no longer in use, it is freed by the GC automatically.

This word is **unsafe**: the resulting Inline struct view is in an undefined state (may contain junk) before you (or the C code you pass it to) fills it with good values. Showing the struct view left by this word to clients may expose your program to a whole class of security vulnerabilities.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:allocateStruct~ $: point~
point~ #x 123 entry:submit
point~ #y 456 entry:submit
point~ toQuote leaves: '~⟨x=123_i32, y=456_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: allocates Inline struct view for the given Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:buildStruct~
words.markdown:
allocates and fills Inline struct view with entries by asking Entry block for them.

If Entry block is missing an entry matching a field that Struct layout form declares, and that field is of type `pointer` or struct reference (`&`), `none` (C nullptr) is used as the value. Dies if Entry block is missing matching entry or entries for fields of other types.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

100 $: x
200 $: y

"Note: `this` has entries called `x` and `y`. `point` has
 fields called `x` and `y`. A match!"
this point ffi:buildStruct~ $: point~

point~ toQuote leaves: '~⟨x=100_i32, y=200_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: allocates and fills Inline struct view with entries by asking Entry block for them.

words.name: ffi:asStruct~
words.markdown:
creates and leaves Inline struct view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

This word is **unsafe**: it does not check whether Address points at something that is layed out according to Struct layout form. Passing 0 (none aka null pointer) for Address will lead to segfault. Passing Address that is outside of your program's memory will lead to segfault. Passing Address that *is* in the bounds of your program's memory, but one not pointing at a struct in accordance with Struct layout form, will lead to undefined behavior (most likely junk values in Inline struct view).

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

100 $: x
200 $: y
this point ffi:buildStruct~ $: point~

point~ ffi:addressof $: addr

addr point ffi:asStruct~ $: addrPoint~
addrPoint~.x leaves: x
addrPoint~.y leaves: y
addrPoint~ toQuote leaves: '~⟨x=100_i32, y=200_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: creates and leaves Inline struct view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:allocateStruct&
words.markdown:
allocates Struct reference view for the given Struct layout form. If the struct is no longer in use, it is freed by the GC automatically.

This word is **unsafe**: the resulting Struct reference view is in an undefined state (may contain junk) before you (or the C code you pass it to) fills it with good values. Showing the struct view left by this word to clients may expose your program to a whole class of security vulnerabilities.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:allocateStruct& $: point&
point& #x 123 entry:submit
point& #y 456 entry:submit
point& toQuote leaves: '&⟨x=123_i32, y=456_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: allocates Struct reference view for the given Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:buildStruct&
words.markdown:
allocates and fills Struct reference view with entries by asking Entry block for them.

If Entry block is missing an entry matching a field that Struct layout form declares, and that field is of type `pointer` or struct reference (`&`), `none` (C nullptr) is used as the value. Dies if Entry block is missing matching entry or entries for fields of other types.

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

100 $: x
200 $: y

"Note: `this` has entries called `x` and `y`. `point` has
 fields called `x` and `y`. A match!"
this point ffi:buildStruct& $: point&

point& toQuote leaves: '&⟨x=100_i32, y=200_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: allocates and fills Struct reference view with entries by asking Entry block for them.

words.name: ffi:asStruct&
words.markdown:
creates and leaves Struct reference view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

This word is **unsafe**: it does not check whether Address points at something that is layed out according to Struct layout form. Passing 0 (none aka null pointer) for Address will lead to segfault. Passing Address that is outside of your program's memory will lead to segfault. Passing Address that *is* in the bounds of your program's memory, but one not pointing at a struct in accordance with Struct layout form, will lead to undefined behavior (most likely junk values in Struct reference view).

```
[ x i32 y i32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

100 $: x
200 $: y
this point ffi:buildStruct& $: point&

point& ffi:addressof $: addr

addr point ffi:asStruct& $: addrPoint&
addrPoint&.x leaves: x
addrPoint&.y leaves: y
addrPoint& toQuote leaves: '&⟨x=100_i32, y=200_i32⟩'
```
words.primer: creates and leaves Struct reference view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:allocateUnion
words.markdown:
allocates Union view for the given Struct layout form.

This word is **unsafe**: the resulting Union view is in an undefined (uninitialized) state (may be zeroed out, contain junk, or both) before you (or the C code you pass it to) fills it with good values. Showing the uninitialized union to clients may expose your program to a whole class of security vulnerabilities.

```
[ chr char
  ord u8
] ffi:createLayout $: quux

quux ffi:allocateUnion $: quuxUnion
quuxUnion #chr 'A' entry:submit
quuxUnion.ord leaves: 65

"Union toQuote avoids printing values, because that could
 cause a segfault/overflow in some cases, and would mostly
 output junk anyway."
quuxUnion toQuote leaves: '(⋃ ⟪chr=char, ord=u8⟫)'
```
words.primer: allocates Union view for the given Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:buildUnion
words.markdown:
allocates and fills Union view with an entry by asking Entry block for any *one* entry out of those specified in Struct layout form, in the order they are specified in Struct layout form. If the union is no longer in use, it is freed by the GC automatically.

Entry block must have at least one of the Struct layout form's fields defined. Otherwise, this word dies.

```
[ chr char
  ord u8
] ffi:createLayout $: quux

[ 'A' $: chr
  this quux ffi:buildUnion
] val $: unionByChr

[ 66 $: ord
  this quux ffi:buildUnion
] val $: unionByOrd

[ 'A' $: chr
  123 $: ord
  this quux ffi:buildUnion
] val $: unionBoth

unionByChr.ord leaves: 65
unionByOrd.chr leaves: 'B'

"'chr' is defined first, therefore, it is used rather
 than 'ord'"
unionBoth.chr leaves: 'A'
unionBoth.ord leaves: 65
```
words.primer: allocates and fills Union view with an entry by asking Entry block for any *one* entry out of those specified in Struct layout form, in the order they are specified in Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:asUnion
words.markdown:
creates and leaves a Union view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

This word is **unsafe**: it does not check whether Address points at something that is layed out according to Struct layout form. Passing 0 (none aka null pointer) for Address will lead to segfault. Passing Address that points outside of your program's memory will lead to segfault. Passing Address that *is* in the bounds of your program's memory, but one not pointing at a union in accordance with Struct layout form, will lead to undefined behavior (most likely junk values in Union view). Showing ill-formed results of this word to clients may expose your program to a whole class of security vulnerabilities.

```
[ chr char
  ord u8
] ffi:createLayout $: quux

'A' $: chr

this quux ffi:buildUnion $: quuxUnion

quuxUnion ffi:addressof $: addr

addr quux ffi:asUnion $: addrUnion
addrUnion.chr leaves: 'A'
addrUnion.ord leaves: 65
```
words.primer: creates and leaves a Union view for the given Address, according to Struct layout form.

words.name: ffi:hole
words.markdown:
allocates garbage-collected memory for Hole that will hold a value of the given Type. If Other hole is passed, wraps that Other hole instead (this could be useful in C situations like `int**`)

Holes are (just a bit) safer way of letting C write to a memory location. You first create the hole, then pass it to C, then read from the hole by opening it.

Note: this word is **unsafe**: since we cannot check whether the hole was written to, reading from hole (opening it) before writing to it will result in undefined behavior.

```
"""
void outputCInt(int* x)
{
  *x = 123;
}
"""

#i32 ffi:hole $: intBox

intBox outputCInt
intBox open leaves: 123
```
words.primer: allocates garbage-collected memory for Hole that will hold a value of the given Type.

words.name: ffi:box
words.markdown:
allocates garbage-collected memory for Type, and writes Form there. Form must be of (or convertible to) Type; otherwise, this word dies. Leaves Address of the beginning of the allocated memory.

```
123 #i32 ffi:box $: ptr
ptr #i32 ffi:unbox leaves: 123
```
words.primer: allocates garbage-collected memory for Type, and writes Form there.

words.name: ffi:unbox
words.markdown:
interprets whatever Address points at as a value of the given Type, and leaves the matching Form. Inverse of `ffi:box`.

This word is **unsafe**: it does not check whether Address points at something that is of the given Type. Passing 0 (none aka null pointer) for Address will lead to segfault. Passing Address that points outside of your program's memory will lead to segfault. Passing Address that *is* in the bounds of your program's memory, but one not pointing at a value of the given Type, will lead to undefined behavior (most likely junk value of Form). Showing ill-formed results of this word to clients, or letting clients control Address or Type, may expose your program to a whole class of security vulnerabilities.

```
123 #i32 ffi:box $: ptr
ptr #i32 ffi:unbox leaves: 123
```
words.primer: interprets whatever Address points at as a value of the given Type, and leaves the matching Form.

words.name: ffi:unsafeWrite
words.markdown:
interprets Form as that of the given Type, and writes it at Address.

This word is **unsafe**: it does not check whether Address can be written to, whether there is enough memory to fully write Form, etc. Passing 0 (none aka null pointer) for Address will lead to segfault. Passing Address that points outside of your program's memory will lead to segfault. Passing Address that *is* in the bounds of your program's memory and can be written to may lead to undefined behavior.

```
#i32 ffi:hole $: myHole
myHole ffi:addressof $: holeAddr
holeAddr 123 #i32 ffi:unsafeWrite
myHole open leaves: 123
```
words.primer: interprets Form as that of the given Type, and writes it at Address.

words.name: ffi:viewLayout
words.markdown:
leaves Struct layout form for the given Struct view form (an inline struct view, struct reference view, or union view).

```
[ x f32 y f32 ] ffi:createLayout $: point

point ffi:allocateStruct& $: point&
point ffi:allocateStruct~ $: point~
point ffi:allocateUnion $: pointU

point& ffi:viewLayout leaves: point
point~ ffi:viewLayout leaves: point
pointU ffi:viewLayout leaves: point
```
words.primer: leaves Struct layout form for the given Struct view form (an inline struct view, struct reference view, or union view).

words.name: ffi:sizeof
words.markdown:
leaves the size of Type, in Bytes.

```
#u8  ffi:sizeof leaves: 1
#u16 ffi:sizeof leaves: 2
#u32 ffi:sizeof leaves: 4
#u64 ffi:sizeof leaves: 8
```
words.primer: leaves the size of Type, in Bytes.

words.name: ffi:addressof
words.markdown:
leaves Address of the given Struct view form (an inline struct view, struct reference view, or union view), or Hole in memory.

```
#i32 ffi:hole $: myHole
myHole ffi:addressof $: holeAddr
holeAddr 123 #i32 ffi:unsafeWrite
myHole open leaves: 123
```
words.primer: leaves Address of the given Struct view form (an inline struct view, struct reference view, or union view), or Hole in memory.
